headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's conference call and webcast corresponding to the first quarter fiscal 2016. The speakers today will be John Lindsay, President and CEO; and me, Juan Tardio. Also, with us today us today is Dave Hard
componenttext: Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's conference call and webcast corresponding to the first quarter fiscal 2016. The speakers today will be John Lindsay, President and CEO; and me, Juan Tardio. Also, with us today us today is Dave Hardy, Manager of Investor Relations. As usual and as defined by the U.S. Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, all forward-looking statements made during this call are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties as discussed in the company's annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. The company's actual results may differ materially from those indicated or implied by such forward-looking statements. We will also be making reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures such as segment operating income and operating statistics. You may find the GAAP reconciliation comments and calculations on the page -- on the last page of today's press release. I will now turn the call over to John Lindsay.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. First fiscal year quarter results were better than expected, primarily as a result of significantly reduced daily rig expenses in our U.S. land segment. Unfortu
componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. First fiscal year quarter results were better than expected, primarily as a result of significantly reduced daily rig expenses in our U.S. land segment. Unfortunately, U.S. land drilling activity has declined to levels not seen since 1999 as very low oil and gas prices are forcing customers to make further reductions in the drilling budgets. The tone in 2016 has shifted to lower for longer. The industry has idled over 1400 rigs in the U.S. since the peak rig count in October of 2014. And it continues to decline. Of those 1400 rigs that have been idled, approximately 900 are legacy SCR mechanical rigs and approximately 500 are AC drive rigs. The industry is experiencing dramatic reductions in personnel and investments and clearly a number of companies are struggling to survive. 
We are unable to predict to the future, but perspective is necessary in both good and bad times. Recently, oil prices traded below $30 a barrel and a few see the possibility of $20 oil. We are predicting an immediate oil price improvement, but we do believe pricing are below the level required to sustain a stable, let alone growing supply over a long period of time. In the meantime, the capabilities of the oilfield service providers are being reduced significantly. At some point, the question will be who is in the best position for the eventual return of drilling demand. We believe that we will be well positioned and that this is simply not a time for us to hunker down and wait for things to get better. While continuing to thoughtfully manage costs, we will prudently investing opportunities that will enhance the key competitive advantages we have in the company.
Let me talk briefly about a few of those opportunities. Our fleet profile is a competitive advantage as the FlexRig design allows us to provide a family of solutions for our customers. For several years now, the industry has been trending toward longer laterals, multi-well pads, and generally, more complex for designs, which require AC drive rigs with 1500-horsepower specifications. We have over 320 AC drive FlexRigs with 1500 horsepower ratings, and over 180 of those rigs are optimized for multi-well pad operations, and we continue to add 7500 psi systems to a large portion of the fleet as well. The advanced fleet of FlexRigs supported by organizational capabilities enables the company to do to remain laser focused on delivering wells safely, quickly and efficiently, while continuing to innovate by providing technology solutions and enhancing our service offering.
Our strategy has been successful. Our market share in the U.S. has increased from 15% in 2014 to 18% today and has doubled since 2008. We will also continue to invest in the organizational capabilities that I just mentioned. This means enhancing our best-in-class reputation for service and the way we create value for our customers., while our organizational infrastructure has been built over the past 10 years, we continue to make investments to improve and deleverage the learnings we captured from the fleet on a daily basis. This allows us to partner more closely with the customer to provide greater efficiencies, reliability and safety. These improvements are all aimed at drilling the lowest cost well for our customers and maximizing the number of wells customers can deliver in a budget year.
And finally, maintaining a strong balance sheet and a disciplined approach to cost management remain a companywide priority. It is in times like that the practice of maintaining a strong balance sheet becomes the key to future success. Along with this, it's having a balanced perspective on cost management so that we're making prudent reductions that loan ended costing us more than the initial saving some somewhere down the line. We're also rightsizing the organization and along the same principles with the end goal of enhancing our performance and developing opportunities for future growth.
Before I turn the call back to Juan Pablo, clearly the first quarter of our 2016 fiscal year has been very challenging start to the year. We are fortunate to have a very strong and liquid balance sheet, a firm backlog of term contracts and the flexibility to significantly reduce spending levels during a soft market. Our approach to capital allocation will remain prudent and should allow us to effectively manage our business through this downturn and a merge from it with even greater competitive advantages. And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Juan Pablo.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. The company reported $16 million in net income for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Given the deterioration of market conditions since late 2014, the average quarterly level of drilling activity for the company has continued to decline d
componenttext:
Thank you, John. The company reported $16 million in net income for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Given the deterioration of market conditions since late 2014, the average quarterly level of drilling activity for the company has continued to decline down 53% from last year's first fiscal quarter and down 11% from last year's fourth fiscal quarter. Unfortunately, activity is expected to continue to significantly decline across our drilling segments during the second fiscal quarter.
Following on some comments on each of our drilling segments. Our U.S. land drilling operations generated approximately $56 million in segment operating income during the first fiscal quarter. The number of quarterly revenue days declined by 11.5% as compared to the prior quarter resulting in an average of approximately 130 rigs generating revenue days during the first fiscal year -- pardon me, during the first fiscal quarter. On average, approximately 104 of these rigs were under our term contract and approximately 26 rigs were in the spot market.
Excluding the impact of early termination revenues, the average rig revenue per day slightly increased to the $26,234 in the first fiscal quarter and the average rig expense per day significantly decreased by $933 to $12,890, resulting in an average rig margin per day of $13,344 in the first fiscal quarter. The decline in the average rig expense per day was primarily a result of continued efforts to reduce field overhead cost and direct operating cost on active rigs. H&P managers and employees across our organization reserve the credit for these very challenging and significant efforts. 
Unfortunately, as I'll mention later -- as I'll also mentioned later, we expect the per day impact of these ongoing efforts to be offset during the second fiscal quarter as our activity levels continue to decline.
During the quarter, the segment generated approximately $29 million in revenues corresponding to early termination of long-term contracts. Given existing notifications for early terminations, we expect to generate over $78 million during the second fiscal quarter, about $77 million during the second half of fiscal 2016 and over $40 million thereafter in early termination revenues. Since the peak in late 2014, we have received early termination notification for a total of 77 rigs under long-term contracts in the segment, up 17 rigs since our last conference call in mid-November. Total early termination revenues related to these 77 contracts are now estimated at approximately $429 million, about $88 million of which corresponds to cash flow previously expected to be generated to normal operations during fiscal 2015, $166 million during fiscal 2016 and $175 million after that. As of today, our 347 available rigs in the U.S. land segment include approximately 121 rigs generating revenue and 226 idle rigs. Included in the 121 rigs generating revenue, are 93 rigs under term contracts, 87 of which are generating revenue days. In addition, 28 rigs are currently active in the spot market for a total of 115 rigs generating revenue days in the segment. Some raids that generate revenue days are on standby type rigs.
Rigs generating revenue and not generating revenue days include 6 new build rigs with deliveries that have been delayed and exchanged for compensation from customers.
Looking ahead to the second quarter of fiscal 2016, we expect revenue days to decrease by close to 20% quarter-to-quarter. Excluding the impact of revenues corresponding to early terminated long-term contracts, we expect our average rig revenue per day to be roughly flat. The average rig expense per day level is expected to increase to roughly $13,600. This expected increase is primarily attributable to the relatively large number of rigs becoming idle during the quarter and impacting total expenses, which are then allocated to a smaller number of expected revenue days. Subject to additional early terminations and excluding rigs for which we have received early termination notifications, the segment already has term contract commitments in place for an average of approximately 87 rigs during the second fiscal quarter, 79 rigs during the second half of fiscal 2016, 66 rigs during fiscal 2017 and 34 rigs during fiscal 2018.
The average pricing for these rigs that are already under term contract is expected to slightly increase and remain strong during the next several quarters as some rigs roll off and the remaining new builds are deployed. The average pricing for H&P rigs in the spot market declined by approximately 5% from last year's fourth fiscal quarter to the first quarter of fiscal 2016 and may continue to decline during the second fiscal quarter. Average spot pricing today is over 30% lower as compared to spot pricing at the peak last November.
Let me now transition to our offshore operations. Segment operating income declined to approximately $8 million from $13 million during the prior quarter. Total revenue days remain flat and the average rig margin per day declined from $13,296 to $7,920 per day during the first fiscal quarter. The decline was mostly attributable to expenses associated with 1 rig mobilizing from shore to a new platform, a second rig of moving from an operating rate to lower standby type day rate and some unexpected downtime during the first quarter. As we look at the second quarter of fiscal 2016, we expect revenue days to decline by 5% to 10% to slightly increase approximately $8,250 during the quarter.
The expected changes are primarily attributable to the full effect of the previously mentioned day rate changes during the first quarter, and 1 rig expected to be mobilized and stacked onshore during the quarter. Management contracts on platform rigs continues to contribute to our offshore segment operating income. Their contribution during the first fiscal quarter was approximately $6 million. Management contracts are expected to generate approximately $3 million during each of the remaining 3 quarters of fiscal 2016.
Moving on to our international land operations. This segment reported operating income of approximately $2 million during the first fiscal quarter, excluding a currency exchange loss of $8.5 million, which was primarily due to the devaluation of the Argentine peso during the quarter. As announced earlier today and starting this fiscal -- this first fiscal quarter, the company eliminated a legacy 1 month lag period between its U.S. fiscal year and its international operations fiscal years. In the past fiscal years for the international operations ended on August 31 instead of September 30 to facilitate reporting of consolidated returns -- sorry, it's the consolidated results. And required, the company applied the elimination of the one-month lag retrospectively to all presented in press release. The average rig margin per day increased sequentially from $8,129 to $11,811 per day excluding the impact of charges related to the allowance for counts during the fourth fiscal quarter. The increase was primarily a result of better-than-expected contribution from multiple rigs in different countries, including rigs that were working on relatively short-term contracts. Revenue days sequentially decreased to an average of 15.3 active rigs during the first fiscal quarter.
As of today, our international land segment have 14 active rigs including 10 in Argentina, 2 in the UAE, 1 in Columbia and 1 in Bahrain. All 14 active rates rigs are under long-term contracts. 24 rigs are idle including 9 in Argentina, 7 in Columbia, 6 in and 2 in Bahrain. We expect international land revenue days to be down 5% to 10% during the second quarter of fiscal 2016. The average rig margin per day is expected to decline to close to $7,500 per day and no early termination revenues are expected during the second fiscal quarter in this segment. The expected decline in average rig margin is primarily attributable to the reduction in activity and day rates of some of our contracted rigs from operating rates to standby type day rates.
Let me now comment on the corporate level details. Our strong liquidity position along with our firm backlog of long-term contracts and reduced CapEx requirements is expected to allow us to sustain our regular dividend dollar per share levels and our intent to is to continue with that plan. Capital expenditures for fiscal 2016 are still expected to be in the range of $300 million to $400 million. Our FlexRigs construction cadence plan remains generally the same with only a few contracted FlexRigs to be completed between now and the end of March 2016. Including these remaining long-term contracts and combining all 3 of our drilling segments, we have an average of approximately 104 rigs under term contract expected to be active in fiscal 2016, 81 in fiscal 2017 and 47 in fiscal 2018.
Given market conditions during the last several months and the early termination of additional long-term contracts, our backlog decreased from approximately $3.1 billion as of September 30, 2015, to approximately $2.7 billion as of December 31, 2015. As mentioned in the past, we expect our total annual depreciation expense for fiscal 2016 to be approximately $580 million, and our general and administrative expenses to be approximately $125 million. The effective income tax rate for the first quarter of fiscal 2016 was higher-than-expected, primarily as a result of adjustments related to the recent tax law changed extending bonus appreciation alliances that expired at the end of 2014.
We expect that effective tax rate for each of the remaining 3 quarters of fiscal 2016 to be in the range of 32% to 35%. With that, let me turn the call back to John.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Juan Pablo. And before opening the call to Q&A, I want to reiterate the challenging oil and gas market today that may be on par with the oil market in the 1980s. But there are key differences and one big difference is the age, size and capability
componenttext: Thanks, Juan Pablo. And before opening the call to Q&A, I want to reiterate the challenging oil and gas market today that may be on par with the oil market in the 1980s. But there are key differences and one big difference is the age, size and capability of today's rig fleet. The AC drive rig replacement cycle of the legacy fleet is ongoing. At the peak of activity in 2014, approximately 41% of the fleet was AC drive. And today, over 63% of the active fleet is AC drive technology. The remaining fleet is legacy SCR and mechanical rigs, and the question remains what will be the marketable legacy fleet at the end of the downtown. We believe that it will be a very small portion of the marketable fleet, and those rigs will have a very difficult time competing in the world of complex, unconventional horizontal wells. And we will now open the call for questions

componenttextpreview: Pablo, as checked by the equation for the U.S. land operations and realize there are lot of moving pieces with more rigs being laid down in the March quarter, but it all sounds that you got that average rig expense per day for typical FlexRigs down to a l
componenttext: Pablo, as checked by the equation for the U.S. land operations and realize there are lot of moving pieces with more rigs being laid down in the March quarter, but it all sounds that you got that average rig expense per day for typical FlexRigs down to a lower sustainable level. So again, I hear the March quarter that is on the cost front, but is it fair to think that you've got that normalized costs down, if you were to back out any costs associated with the leaks that will be laid down in the March quarter? I'm just trying to think about how that flows as we get deeper into the fiscal year and beyond.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Byron. This is Pablo. I think that is fair, however, going forward it all depends on the number of idle rigs and active rigs and the corresponding proportion, of course. In terms of how many idle rigs we will have that will be subject to some s
componenttext: Thank you, Byron. This is Pablo. I think that is fair, however, going forward it all depends on the number of idle rigs and active rigs and the corresponding proportion, of course. In terms of how many idle rigs we will have that will be subject to some small level of fixed expenses that will impact the total expenses that will then be allocated only among the very smaller or relatively small number of revenue days. As that denominator get smaller, it just has an impact on the total average and that's what we see happening the following quarter. But I think, your point is a good one that, in general, we've made great strides in an organization to continue to reduce the average expense per active rig is just that the inactive ones are creating some volatility.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Byron, this is John. Pablo said in his comments, but the guys in the field that work really, really hard to get those costs down and they have. They have done a great job, but like Pablo said, the denominator small number of days to spread those costs ove
componenttext: Byron, this is John. Pablo said in his comments, but the guys in the field that work really, really hard to get those costs down and they have. They have done a great job, but like Pablo said, the denominator small number of days to spread those costs over. And I think -- but there is also things that we're working on related to just costs on the supply chain side. There is lot of things that we're excited about working on, but again, obviously we've got a large number of rigs that are idle today.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, in the past you've mentioned a possible structural change in the industry especially in relation to preserving the dividend at current levels. But given where we are in terms of the oil rig count being less than the rigs out there in the market, wou
componenttext: John, in the past you've mentioned a possible structural change in the industry especially in relation to preserving the dividend at current levels. But given where we are in terms of the oil rig count being less than the rigs out there in the market, would you view this as a structural change or the oversupply AC rigs just to kind of temporary phenomenon on your opinion?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't consider this as a structural change. I see it as a really classic cyclical market at this stage. I mean, if we lived back in history, you can see while -- pretty while swings and down cycles in terms of the number of rigs that are going dow
componenttext: Well, I don't consider this as a structural change. I see it as a really classic cyclical market at this stage. I mean, if we lived back in history, you can see while -- pretty while swings and down cycles in terms of the number of rigs that are going down. You're right, there are over 900 AC rigs available today, not all AC rigs are created equal. There is -- I think, when you begin to see oil prices improve in the future, I don't know when that is, nobody knows, but there is going to be high demand for those assets in the future. I think the real challenge as it relates to the rig fleet and that's the legacy fleet, which we've addressed over a pretty long period of time is just going to be harder and harder for those rigs to be competitive. So that's a long answer to your question, but no, I don't -- we don't see this as a structural change at this point.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. As a follow on to that. There has been a lot of talk, or I guess, I should say, some talk of some significant attrition in the pressure pumping market in terms of equipment. But really don't hear back from the land rig side in terms of through attri
componenttext: Okay. As a follow on to that. There has been a lot of talk, or I guess, I should say, some talk of some significant attrition in the pressure pumping market in terms of equipment. But really don't hear back from the land rig side in terms of through attrition from mechanical SCR rigs. Could you share your thoughts on that as well?

componenttext: So I wanted to just to talk a little bit more about the day rates on U.S. onshore. I'm assuming the guidance some mix shift benefit is more of the side rigs link contracted rigs. With the rig count taking a write-down, are you seeing -- is the mentality shifting amongst your peers at all in terms of -- towards the utilization of any price mentality or do believe that the markets level of discipline is holding firm?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sean, I -- this is John. I -- the reality is there isn't -- and it's been this way really since the downtown got into the full swing. There isn't much of a spot market to speak of. And so there is not -- it's not like there's a lot of competition out ther
componenttext: Sean, I -- this is John. I -- the reality is there isn't -- and it's been this way really since the downtown got into the full swing. There isn't much of a spot market to speak of. And so there is not -- it's not like there's a lot of competition out there for jobs. What few jobs are out there, the customer knows what they want. They know what the market rate is. There is not -- at least, from our perspective, there is not a huge push on those rates at very, very low levels. I mean, obviously, there is competitors out there pricing to certain extent irrationally and maybe rational from our perspective, but from their perspective, it may be what they need to do. But there's just not a lot of work out they are being bid on. So I wouldn't at this stage, said that anybody strategy on pricing is going to deliver any improvement in market share at this stage of the game.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, that's very fair. So I guess, we think about -- we've heard some and fill EMTs with budgets in the last couple of days to small samples but indication for substantial capitalization issues again after we saw in 2015, just curious how you see dril
componenttext: I think, that's very fair. So I guess, we think about -- we've heard some and fill EMTs with budgets in the last couple of days to small samples but indication for substantial capitalization issues again after we saw in 2015, just curious how you see drilling efficiencies unfolding for the industry as a whole in '16, and we continue to shrink down the level of activity.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look back at least at our performance going back to 2011, we've had double-digit performance improvement in terms of footage per day every year since 2011 with the exception of 13 to 14 or 14 activity really spiked up, it was high single digits. Th
componenttext: If you look back at least at our performance going back to 2011, we've had double-digit performance improvement in terms of footage per day every year since 2011 with the exception of 13 to 14 or 14 activity really spiked up, it was high single digits. This year, we've got again high double digits improvement. But obviously, there is a point of diminishing returns on what's capable of happening out there. And so, I think, there will continue to be some performance improvement year-over-year. I would imagine that a large portion of that performance improvement is going to be related to Permian, because the other basins have been drilling horizontal wells for a much longer period of time, and I would suspect that Permian is going to drive the overall industry in terms of whatever that performance improvement will be year-over-year, does that make sense. But I don't really have a feel for -- I mean, my sense is that it's not going to continue to be at high double-digit type performance year-over-year.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a lot of sense. Then just the last to take it to the other side, recovery, would you expect industrial to get back then some of those efficiencies for a period of time?
componenttext: That makes a lot of sense. Then just the last to take it to the other side, recovery, would you expect industrial to get back then some of those efficiencies for a period of time?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if it's an H&P rig, I would say, no. I can't really speak to anybody else. No. I think, early on, I wouldn't expect that, but at least, I'm thinking about from our own fleet, it's hard for me to speak for anyone else's. But clearly what's the amount
componenttext: Well, if it's an H&P rig, I would say, no. I can't really speak to anybody else. No. I think, early on, I wouldn't expect that, but at least, I'm thinking about from our own fleet, it's hard for me to speak for anyone else's. But clearly what's the amount of reductions and we talked about this on our comments, not only is there a much lower level of budgets, but we have had a lot of -- of course, there is a lot of folks leave the industry, we've had a lot of reductions in that respect. And that's -- that ultimately ends up being a bottleneck in a lot of cases when you begin to take the industry the other direction. So I think, that could be a challenge for the industry, in general.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Maybe to follow up on Sean's question along the lines of productivity, whether it's from per rig or per well standpoint, is it fair to say in your estimation that maybe some of those statistics is resilient as production has been distorted a little bit by high grading of acreage in crudes and rigs, and if so, I guess, that a similar trend they envision in terms of diminishing returns from productivity standpoint?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think there is any doubt that the wells that are being drilled are the best wells. I mean, it would just make sense that's what going on. And of course, we have -- you would think everyone will have their best people both on the operator side
componenttext: Yes, I don't think there is any doubt that the wells that are being drilled are the best wells. I mean, it would just make sense that's what going on. And of course, we have -- you would think everyone will have their best people both on the operator side, on the service side, the contractor side, I mean, it's the best of the best. So I think all of that -- all of that make sense. And if you were to take the industry and increase the rig count by a couple of hundred rigs, it would be hard press to have the same as efficiency level across the industry, I would suspect.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. That make snse. And maybe, thinking at least theoretically, when things do begin to recover and customers start engaging in a conversation about reactivation seems to be a sort of a popular motion with some investors that it's going to be very diffi
componenttext: Sure. That make snse. And maybe, thinking at least theoretically, when things do begin to recover and customers start engaging in a conversation about reactivation seems to be a sort of a popular motion with some investors that it's going to be very difficult to get any sort of pricing traction to reactivate a rig. I'd love you take on that. Obviously, it doesn't sound like there is much incremental investment necessary to bring a rig out of the but how would you envision those conversations solely?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, historically, what you said is right. And I think that, that probably -- that probably holds true going forward. I think, initially, you're not going to see a pricing improvement. You're right, at least in our fleet, there should be a high level of
componenttext: Well, historically, what you said is right. And I think that, that probably -- that probably holds true going forward. I think, initially, you're not going to see a pricing improvement. You're right, at least in our fleet, there should be a high level of investment in order to reactivate a rig. I think, we've done a very good job in terms of idling our assets and preserving them. And there is a set of weights that are ready to go back to work when that time would happen. And so I think that -- I think that's true. I do think there is a point in time really begin to gain a little bit of traction, because I think the rigs that are going to be desired in the industry are going to be obviously the best rigs, and they are going to have higher horsepower, they're going to have greater need related to  again a third sort of a 75,00 psi pad application  There is going to be more investment and that investment drives a greater level of performance. So I think, there is an opportunity to get pricing up, but it won't be at the very beginning of the cycle. I think, we'll have to put some rakes back to work and improve the utilization levels for the AC fleet before you would see pricing improvements, I would suspect.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Maybe, I'll start with a clarification from Byron's question initially. He was asking you're sort of went normalized costs. And it sounds like you said yes, but it was all contingent on the denominator. So maybe just, so what I understand what you're suggesting, if you think about the third fiscal quarter -- if we think about the third fiscal quarter and if the rig count were to stay flat, is that operating cost per day of 13,600 for U.S. onshore, is that the right -- is that a reasonable expectation in light of the fact of the denominator is what it is?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, this is Juan Pablo. Let me give you some additional color in terms of what I was referring to it. If you -- at any time, there is a significant transition in terms of whether it's an increase in the rig count or a decrease, but there is a lot of act
componenttext: Brad, this is Juan Pablo. Let me give you some additional color in terms of what I was referring to it. If you -- at any time, there is a significant transition in terms of whether it's an increase in the rig count or a decrease, but there is a lot of activities that take place related to those rigs to transport and waited to make sure that we rig them up in the right way and preparing to go back to work, et cetera. On the other hand, if you might recall in years past when we've had a transmission from 1 region to another region, whether it's from related to preference of price for oil as compared to gas and we have a lot of transition, that adds up to our cost and has typically an unfavorable impact on our average rig expense per day for the quarter. That's what we see happening in the second fiscal quarter. Given your assumption, going into the third quarter and everything else being equal, I think that there is a potential for that average to come down, but there is always other considerations to keep in mind and will just have to follow that and report on that during the corresponding conference call.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Understood. That make sense. Consistent with the answer on a normalized cost being That's great. Understood. Unrelated follow-up. So John, in your comments, I was trying to tie your comments around what you're doing with rigs through the course of this year with some of what you wrote in your -- in the narrative on the front of the press release and on upgrades, continuously upgrading your best-in-class rigs. Should we think of that being related to either adding a third pump or upgrading it to 7500-psi, is that the most important change to your rigs as you think about fiscal '16?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a portion. There is additional horsepower requirements at times. It's a third pump, it's 7500. There is other upgrades. It really does state that we haven't talked a lot about and don't intend to today. But the majority on the cost side, I would s
componenttext: That is a portion. There is additional horsepower requirements at times. It's a third pump, it's 7500. There is other upgrades. It really does state that we haven't talked a lot about and don't intend to today. But the majority on the cost side, I would say, yes, that's the portion that there was -- you would see a larger CapEx exposure. There is other things that we're working on that are as highly on the CapEx side, but deliver some value. I mean, our -- I mean, as you follow this for a long time, our goal is to continuously upgrade and improve the company, not just the rigs, but the structures and processes and systems and tools that we have. So we pride ourselves in doing that and that's what we're doing. And that obviously has a price tag to it as well.

componenttext: A question for you on the cost side, again, specifically in the U.S. How much of your reduction in operating cost so far if any has related to permanent reductions and competition for your employees that remain employed, and how you do you think about that concept of cutting salaries or wages going forward for people that remain employed?

componenttext: The last part, I'm not certain I've got all of the first part of the question. I'll turn that over to Juan Pablo. The second part of the question is we haven't, we haven't reduced wages, we hadn't increased wages since December 2011. And wages, I think, you probably know this, but just to restate, wages are typically a direct cost to our customers so that is really -- that is not the savings there for us. And -- so at this stage, we don't have any indication that we're going to reduce our wages for our folks in the field. You've anything to add?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, that is consistent to what I think Rob was asking related to reduction that we've seen so far. None related to wages, as John mentioned. Certainly, we have to deal with over just at times, and so managing the logistics around the personnel, that's a
componenttext: John, that is consistent to what I think Rob was asking related to reduction that we've seen so far. None related to wages, as John mentioned. Certainly, we have to deal with over just at times, and so managing the logistics around the personnel, that's a huge challenge. And we've done as an organization a great job so far in that regard throughout the downturn. So that has an impact on total expenses, but the reduction and expense per day has been a result of several factors within the maintenance, efficiency with, which we get have been managing crudes, other related costs, et cetera, I can't give you specific example, but it's been overall a great effort.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it is clearly particularly with the expense per day after this quarter being below what you posted in 12, 13 and 14. I guess, another way to ask a similar question would be, structurally, when we end the transition process, we end the dropping the rig
componenttext: No, it is clearly particularly with the expense per day after this quarter being below what you posted in 12, 13 and 14. I guess, another way to ask a similar question would be, structurally, when we end the transition process, we end the dropping the rigs and market find if you will find the new bottom or find the steady state new level, we do you think that rig expense per day operating level is, given all the more you've made, once the volatility ends.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a great question. I don't have a number for you Robert, but I can't say that we're continuing to look at all the options available and understanding our costs as best as we can, and from an organizational perspective, the structure of the org
componenttext: Well, that's a great question. I don't have a number for you Robert, but I can't say that we're continuing to look at all the options available and understanding our costs as best as we can, and from an organizational perspective, the structure of the organization, how we can become a leaner and more efficient as a company, I mean, there is all of those things are on the table and we're looking at. I think, the other thing to keep in mind all during this time is the rigs have continued to work harder and harder. So the wells we're drilling today are nothing like the wells we drilled 2 years ago. So when you look at and our cost trends over time, Pablo said, our folks have done a great job. When you consider the amount of footage that we drilled in a year-to-date compared to what we did 3 years ago, these rigs are working somewhat harder, that rig more times are much less frequent, you're spending less time moving, you're spending more time drilling. And you're using for example, much more frequently. So the fact that we've able to get our cost over time is pretty amazing. So that part of the challenges that we have is the variables are not held constant, they are continuing to change on an upward fashion. So we're having to work against that at the same time.

And so we may be invoicing some work on early termination fees that are deferred and so and the liability side of the balance sheet impacts either cash or receivables, et cetera. So we have those types of moving variables, but overall, we're very pleased with how the working capital is progressing, in general, no issues to comment on on receivables, no issues to comment on about any other variables. It's great to have the very high level of liquidity that we have today. Obviously, that is partly a result of the early termination fees that we've mentioned. It is held by the allowance for bonus depreciation that we mentioned as well. We're very pleased to be where we are from the balance sheet standpoint.

So it's definitely something we have interest in you followed us for a long time, the challenges associated with growing a significant way internationally, but obviously, we're open to having those discussions and making that happen.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we continue to believe that international has some real upside for us. You've probably heard us say for a long time now that when unconventional resource plays become more popular, become more economic and, if you will, internationally that business,
componenttext: Yes, we continue to believe that international has some real upside for us. You've probably heard us say for a long time now that when unconventional resource plays become more popular, become more economic and, if you will, internationally that business, we are to be in a position to take advantage of that opportunity. Obviously, the work in Argentina is really the first kind of large scale, unconventional resource play opportunity and we have more market share than anybody else. So I think, it presents some great opportunities in the future. We've worked internationally for over 50 years. We have a lot of experience, and of course, we have a lot of more we can learn. We know we can do better. So it is a desire of the company to continue to try to grow our footprint internationally, and obviously, we have the assets and the personal to make that happen to do.

Could you just give an update on where you think you're at with that, that next phase of technological differentiation?

componenttext: Yes, Tom, that's a great question. There's a lot of things that we do with the data that helps us run our business better. As far as maintenance and rig equipment and that equipment running at high levels and performing well, the challenge -- and we utilize that data to help the rig drill more quickly for our customers. But when you begin to -- when you're working for a lot of different customers and there's a lot of different needs and desires on how that data gets used and that's manage. So I see it as -- we still see it as an opportunity. Don't have perfect clarity on to how that looks going forward. But the other thing that we've said is because our fleet is all AC drive rigs and because of our fleet is a uniform fleet and we have the ability to share that information, whatever that breakthrough may end up looking like in the future, I think, we're in a better position than others in order to take advantage of that, whatever that might be. There is definitely some challenges associated with the right now if you look at it across-the-board because of all the different folks that you're looking for. Does that make sense?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I have is, so what is the variable cash cost per day for running an H&P rig right now?
componenttext: First question I have is, so what is the variable cash cost per day for running an H&P rig right now?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have an exact number for you, but that's a very fair question because it goes to the heart of some of the moving considerations or variables related to our total average expense by day. Some of those expenses relates to rigs that are not active.
componenttext: We don't have an exact number for you, but that's a very fair question because it goes to the heart of some of the moving considerations or variables related to our total average expense by day. Some of those expenses relates to rigs that are not active. So if you are talking only about active rigs, then the number would be lower. Then if you also subtract other revenue that we -- that may relate to that rig, whether it's related to H&P trucking or whether it's related to other services, whether it's rentals, et cetera, then that number continues to go down. And it also depends on the region that you are in and the cost structure between regions, of course, as you know, it's significantly different. So I think, a fair assumption is that the cash cost directly associated with the rig and without any other ancillary revenues is significantly lower than our average rig expense per day. But then of course, you also have maintenance CapEx consideration that, of course, you'll probably included -- including conceptually on that cash cost question and that depends on the rig that you're looking at, if it's a new rig, your maintenance CapEx is much lower if you can imagine to unfold the rig, et cetera. So too many moving variables to give you an answer, but I think, it's a fair question and it's an important consideration in terms of pricing and competitive advantageous going forward, we think, we're very well positioned in that regard given uniformity of our fleet, the way that we maintain our rigs and several other considerations.

componenttext: Chase, this is John. Gosh, I wish we had that problem to worry that doesn't sound like a great situation. That's a tough 1 to call right now. I mean, when you consider a number of rigs that we have idle, not only us, but the overall industry, obviously, we've seen it before, we've seen this market done very quickly and it could get better. We've obviously built new rigs on spec before. You know what our preference has been. So I mean, we'll be foolish to say, hey, we're going to completely rule it out, but there's a lot of different considerations you're going to take into account. But at this stage, I think, anything would be on the table if there is a market there for that type of opportunity, nobody can respond more quickly than H&P, nobody has the ability to build a quality AC rig at the cost that we're able to do it. So it's a great opportunity for us. Again, I look forward to having that opportunity.

componenttext: Well, I just want to thank all of you again for joining us this morning. I'm just trying to make a couple of more just brief comments before we sign off. You've heard Juan Pablo and I describe that this remains a very challenging environment, but we do believe the company is very well positioned. Our long-term contracts continue to protect our investments and overall, our customer base remains resilient. The balance sheet is in great shape, our customer base remains strong and our competitive advantages have positioned us to manage through this cycle and the cash opportunities when they emerge. We continue to work very hard to improve the capabilities of the company. We have a lot of very important initiatives ongoing. I want to thank all our employees and our management teams for stepping up to the challenges that we have faced, embracing this change in a positive way and responding in an admirable fashion. So again, we appreciate all of you for joining us this morning. And we thank you for your continued support.

It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Vice President and CFO, Mr. Juan Pablo Tardio. Please go ahead.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's conference call and webcast corresponding to the first quarter fiscal 2016. The speakers today will be John Lindsay, President and CEO; and me, Juan Pablo Tardio. Also, with us today is Dave Hardie,
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's conference call and webcast corresponding to the first quarter fiscal 2016. The speakers today will be John Lindsay, President and CEO; and me, Juan Pablo Tardio. Also, with us today is Dave Hardie, Manager of Investor Relations. 
As usual and as defined by the U.S. Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, all forward-looking statements made during this call are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties as discussed in the company's annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. The company's actual results may differ materially from those indicated or implied by such forward-looking statements. We will also be making reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures such as segment operating income and operating statistics. You may find the GAAP reconciliation comments and calculations on the page -- on the last page of today's press release. 
I will now turn the call over to John Lindsay.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. Our first fiscal quarter results were better than expected, primarily as a result of significantly reduced daily rig expenses in our U.S. land segment. Unfortun
componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call today. Our first fiscal quarter results were better than expected, primarily as a result of significantly reduced daily rig expenses in our U.S. land segment. Unfortunately, U.S. land drilling activity has declined to levels not seen since 1999 as very low oil and gas prices are forcing customers to make further reductions in the drilling budgets. 
The tone in 2016 has shifted to lower for longer. The industry has idled over 1,400 rigs in the U.S. since the peak rig count in October of 2014, and it continues to decline. Of those 1,400 rigs that have been idled, approximately 900 are legacy SCR and mechanical rigs, and approximately 500 are AC drive rigs. The industry is experiencing dramatic reductions in personnel and investments. And clearly, a number of companies are struggling to survive.
We are unable to predict to the future, but perspective is necessary in both good and bad times. Recently, oil prices traded below $30 a barrel, and a few pundits see the possibility of $20 oil. We are predicting an immediate oil price improvement, but we do believe prices are below the level required to sustain a stable, let alone growing supply over a long period of time. In the meantime, the capabilities of the oilfield service providers are being reduced significantly. 
At some point, the question will be who is in the best position for the eventual return of drilling demand. We believe that we will be well positioned and that this is simply not a time for us to hunker down and wait for things to get better. While continuing to thoughtfully manage costs, we will prudently invest in opportunities that will enhance the key competitive advantages we have in the company.
Let me talk briefly about a few of those opportunities. Our fleet profile is a competitive advantage as the FlexRig design allows us to provide a family of solutions for our customers. For several years now, the industry has been trending toward longer laterals, multi-well pads, and generally, more complex for designs, which require AC drive rigs with 1,500-horsepower specifications. We have over 320 AC drive FlexRigs with 1,500-horsepower rating. And over 180 of those rigs are optimized for multi-well pad operations. And we continue to add 7,500 psi mud systems to a large portion of the fleet as well. 
The advanced fleet of FlexRigs, supported by our organizational capabilities, enables the company to remain laser focused on delivering wells safely, quickly and efficiently while continuing to innovate by providing technology solutions and enhancing our service offering.
Our strategy has been successful. Our market share in the U.S. has increased from 15% in 2014 to 18% today and has doubled since 2008. We will also continue to invest in the organizational capability that I just mentioned. This means enhancing our best-in-class reputation for service and the way we create value for our customers. 
While our organizational infrastructure has been built over the past 10 years, we continue to make investments to improve and deleverage the learnings we capture from the fleet on a daily basis. This allows us to partner more closely with the customer to provide greater efficiencies, reliability and safety. These improvements are all aimed at drilling the lowest-cost well for our customers and maximizing the number of wells customers can deliver in a budget year.
And finally, maintaining a strong balance sheet and a disciplined approach to cost management remain a company-wide priority. It is in times like these that the practice of maintaining a strong balance sheet becomes the key to future success. Along with this, it's having a balanced perspective on cost management, so that we're making prudent reductions that won't end up costing us more than the initial saving somewhere down the line. We're also rightsizing the organization along these same principles with the end goal of enhancing our performance and developing opportunities for future growth.
Before I turn the call back to Juan Pablo, clearly, the first quarter of our 2016 fiscal year has been a very challenging start to the year. We are fortunate to have a very strong and liquid balance sheet, a firm backlog of term contracts and the flexibility to significantly reduce spending levels during a soft market. Our approach to capital allocation will remain prudent and should allow us to effectively manage our business through this downturn and emerge from it with even greater competitive advantages. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Juan Pablo.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. The company reported $16 million in net income for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Given the deterioration of market conditions since late 2014, the average quarterly level of drilling activity for the company has continued to decline,
componenttext:
Thank you, John. The company reported $16 million in net income for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Given the deterioration of market conditions since late 2014, the average quarterly level of drilling activity for the company has continued to decline, down 53% from last year's first fiscal quarter and down 11% from last year's fourth fiscal quarter. Unfortunately, activity is expected to continue to significantly decline across our drilling segments during the second fiscal quarter.
Following are some comments on each of our drilling segments. Our U.S. land drilling operations generated approximately $56 million in segment operating income during the first fiscal quarter. The number of quarterly revenue days declined by 11.5% as compared to the prior quarter, resulting in an average of approximately 130 rigs generating revenue days during the first fiscal year -- pardon me, during the first fiscal quarter. On average, approximately 104 of these rigs were under term contracts, and approximately 26 rigs were in the spot market.
Excluding the impact of early termination revenues, the average rig revenue per day slightly increased to $26,234 in the first fiscal quarter. And the average rig expense per day significantly decreased by $933 to $12,890, resulting in an average rig margin per day of $13,344 in the first fiscal quarter. The decline in the average rig expense per day was primarily a result of continued efforts to reduce field overhead cost and direct operating cost on active rigs. 
H&P managers and employees across our organization reserve the credit for these very challenging and significant efforts.
Unfortunately, as I'll also mention later, we expect the per-day impact of these ongoing efforts to be offset during the second fiscal quarter as our activity levels continue to decline.
During the quarter, the segment generated approximately $29 million in revenues corresponding to early termination of long-term contracts. Given existing notifications for early terminations, we expect to generate over $78 million during the second fiscal quarter, about $77 million during the second half of fiscal 2016, and over $40 million thereafter in early termination revenues. 
Since the peak in late 2014, we have received early termination notifications for a total of 77 rigs under long-term contracts in the segment, up 17 rigs since our last conference call in mid-November. 
Total early termination revenues related to these 77 contracts are now estimated at approximately $429 million, about $88 million of which corresponds to cash flow previously expected to be generated through normal operations during fiscal 2015, $166 million during fiscal 2016, and $175 million after that. 
As of today, our 347 available rigs in the U.S. land segment include approximately 121 rigs generating revenue and 226 idle rigs. Included in the 121 rigs generating revenue are 93 rigs under term contracts, 87 of which are generating revenue days. In addition, 28 rigs are currently active in the spot market, for a total of 115 rigs generating revenue days in the segment. Some rigs that generate revenue days are on standby-type day rates.
Rigs generating revenue and not generating revenue days include 6 new build rigs with deliveries that have been delayed and exchanged for compensation from customers.
Looking ahead to the second quarter of fiscal 2016, we expect revenue days to decrease by close to 20% quarter-to-quarter. Excluding the impact of revenues corresponding to early terminated long-term contracts, we expect our average rig revenue per day to be roughly flat. The average rig expense per day level is expected to increase to roughly $13,600. This expected increase is primarily attributable to the relatively large number of rigs becoming idle during the quarter and impacting total expenses, which are then allocated to a smaller number of expected revenue days. 
Subject to additional early terminations and excluding rigs for which we have received early termination notifications, the segment already has term contract commitments in place for an average of approximately 87 rigs during the second fiscal quarter; 79 rigs during the second half of fiscal 2016; 66 rigs during fiscal 2017; and 34 rigs during fiscal 2018.
The average pricing for these rigs that are already under term contract is expected to slightly increase and remain strong during the next several quarters as some rigs roll off and the remaining new builds are deployed. 
The average pricing for H&P rigs in the spot market declined by approximately 5% from last year's fourth fiscal quarter to the first quarter of fiscal 2016 and may continue to decline during the second fiscal quarter. Average spot pricing today is over 30% lower as compared to spot pricing at the peak last November.
Let me now transition to our offshore operations. Segment operating income declined to approximately $8 million from $13 million during the prior quarter. Total revenue days remained flat, and the average rig margin per day declined from $13,296 to $7,920 per day during the first fiscal quarter. The decline was mostly attributable to expenses associated with one rig mobilizing from shore to a new platform, a second rig moving from an operating rate to lower standby-type day rate and some unexpected downtime during the first quarter. 
As we look at the second quarter of fiscal 2016, we expect revenue days to decline by 5% to 10% and the average rig margin per day to slightly increase approximately to $8,250 during the quarter.
The expected changes are primarily attributable to the full effect of the previously mentioned day rate changes during the first quarter and one rig expected to be demobilized and stacked onshore during the quarter. 
Management contracts from platform rigs continue to contribute to our offshore segment operating income. Their contribution during the first fiscal quarter was approximately $6 million. Management contracts are expected to generate approximately $3 million during each of the remaining 3 quarters of fiscal 2016.
Moving on to our international land operations. This segment reported operating income of approximately $2 million during the first fiscal quarter, excluding a currency exchange loss of $8.5 million, which was primarily due to the devaluation of the Argentine peso during the quarter. 
As announced earlier today and starting this fiscal -- this first fiscal quarter, the company eliminated a legacy 1-month lag period between its U.S. fiscal year and its international operations' fiscal years. And the past fiscal years for the international operations ended on August 31 instead of September 30 to facilitate reporting of consolidated returns -- that is of consolidated results. 
As required, the company applied the elimination of the 1-month lag retrospectively to all periods presented in today's press release. The average rig margin per day increased sequentially from $8,129 to $11,811 per day, excluding the impact of charges related to the allowance for doubtful accounts during the fourth fiscal quarter. The increase was primarily a result of better-than-expected contribution from multiple rigs in different countries, including rigs that were working on relatively short-term contracts. Revenue days sequentially decreased to an average of 15.3 active rigs during the first fiscal quarter.
As of today, our international land segment have 14 active rigs, including 10 in Argentina, 2 in the UAE, 1 in Columbia and 1 in Bahrain. All 14 active rigs are under long-term contracts. 24 rigs are idle, including 9 in Argentina, 7 in Columbia, 6 in Ecuador and 2 in Bahrain. 
We expect international land quarterly revenue days to be down 5% to 10% during the second quarter of fiscal 2016. The average rig margin per day is expected to decline to close to $7,500 per day, and no early termination revenues are expected during the second fiscal quarter in the segment. The expected decline in average rig margin is primarily attributable to the reduction in activity and to day rates for some of our contracted rigs moving from operating rates to standby-type day rates.
Let me now comment on the corporate-level details. Our strong liquidity position, along with our firm backlog of long-term contracts and reduced CapEx requirement, is expected to allow us to sustain our regular dividend dollar-per-share levels, and our intent to is to continue with that plan. 
Capital expenditures for fiscal 2016 are still expected to be in the range of $300 million to $400 million. Our FlexRig construction cadence plan remains generally the same, with only a few contracted FlexRigs to be completed between now and the end of March of 2016. 
Including these remaining long-term contracts and combining all 3 of our drilling segments, we have an average of approximately 104 rigs under termed contracts expected to be active in fiscal 2016, 81 in fiscal 2017 and 47 in fiscal 2018.
Given market conditions during the last several months and the early termination of additional long-term contracts, our backlog decreased from approximately $3.1 billion as of September 30, 2015, to approximately $2.7 billion as of December 31, 2015. As mentioned in the past, we expect our total annual depreciation expense for fiscal 2016 to be approximately $580 million, and our general and administrative expenses to be approximately $135 million. The effective income tax rate for the first quarter of fiscal 2016 was higher than expected, primarily as a result of adjustments related to the recent tax law change extending bonus appreciation allowances that expired at the end of 2014. We expect that effective tax rate for each of the remaining 3 quarters of fiscal 2016 to be in the range of 32% to 35%. 
With that, let me turn the call back to John.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Juan Pablo. And before opening the call to Q&A, I want to reiterate the challenging oil and gas market today that may be on par with the oil market in the 1980s. But there are key differences, and one big difference is the age, size and capability
componenttext:
Thanks, Juan Pablo. And before opening the call to Q&A, I want to reiterate the challenging oil and gas market today that may be on par with the oil market in the 1980s. But there are key differences, and one big difference is the age, size and capability of today's rig fleet. The AC drive rig replacement cycle of the legacy fleet is ongoing. At the peak of activity in 2014, approximately 41% of the fleet was AC drive. And today, over 63% of the active fleet is AC drive technology. The remaining fleet is legacy SCR and mechanical rigs. And the question remains, what will be the marketable legacy fleet at the end of the downturn? We believe it will be a very small portion of the marketable fleet, and those rigs will have a very difficult time competing in the world of complex, unconventional horizontal wells. 
And we will now open the call for questions, Keith.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we can take our first question from Byron Pope with Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we can take our first question from Byron Pope with Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, what was -- or Juan Pablo, I was struck by the cost side of the equation for U.S. land operations and realized there are a lot of moving pieces with more -- is it rigs being laid down in the March quarter? But it almost sounds as though you've gotte
componenttext: John, what was -- or Juan Pablo, I was struck by the cost side of the equation for U.S. land operations and realized there are a lot of moving pieces with more -- is it rigs being laid down in the March quarter? But it almost sounds as though you've gotten that average rig expense per day for a typical FlexRig down to maybe a lower sustainable level. So again, I'd back here that March quarter guidance on the cost front. But is it fair to think that you've gotten that normalized costs down if you were to back out any costs associated with the rigs that will be laid down in the March quarter? I'm just trying to think about how that flows as we get deeper into this fiscal year and beyond.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Byron. This is Juan Pablo. I think that is fair. However, we -- going forward, it all depends on the number of idle rigs and active rigs and the corresponding proportion, of course. In terms of how many idle rigs we will have, that will be subj
componenttext: Thank you, Byron. This is Juan Pablo. I think that is fair. However, we -- going forward, it all depends on the number of idle rigs and active rigs and the corresponding proportion, of course. In terms of how many idle rigs we will have, that will be subject to some small level of fixed expenses that will impact the total expenses that will then be allocated only among the very smaller or relatively small number of revenue days. As that denominator gets smaller, it just has an impact on the total average. And that's what we see happening the following quarter. But I think your point is a good one that in general, we've made great strides as an organization to continue to reduce the average expense per active rig. It's just that the inactive ones are creating some volatility.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Byron, this is John. Juan Pablo said in his comments, but the guys in the field had worked really, really hard to get those costs down, and they have. They have done a great job. But like Juan Pablo said, there's the denominator. It's the small number of
componenttext: Byron, this is John. Juan Pablo said in his comments, but the guys in the field had worked really, really hard to get those costs down, and they have. They have done a great job. But like Juan Pablo said, there's the denominator. It's the small number of days to spread those costs over. And I think -- but there's also things that we're working on related to just costs on the supply chain side. There's lot of things that we're excited about working on. But again, obviously, we've got a large number of rigs that are idle today.
