headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call may be recorded. I will be standing by if you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. J
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call may be recorded. I will be standing by if you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Juan Pablo Tardio, Vice President and CFO. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tanishia. And welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's conference call and webcast corresponding to the second quarter of fiscal 2016. The speakers today will be John Lindsay, President and CEO; and me, Juan Pablo Tardio. Also with us today is
componenttext:
Thank you, Tanishia. And welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's conference call and webcast corresponding to the second quarter of fiscal 2016. The speakers today will be John Lindsay, President and CEO; and me, Juan Pablo Tardio. Also with us today is Dave Hardie, Manager of Investor Relations.
As usual and as defined by the U.S. Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, all forward-looking statements made during this call are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties as discussed in the company's annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. The company's actual results may differ materially from those indicated or implied by such forward-looking statements. We will also be making reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as segment operating income and operating statistics. You may find the GAAP reconciliation comments and calculations on the last page of today's press release.
I will now turn the call over to John Lindsay.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on the call this morning.Last week, [indiscernible], a well-known investor, dubbed the American oil industry as dead on the water that for multiple quarters of capital starv
componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on the call this morning.
Last week, [indiscernible], a well-known investor, dubbed the American oil industry as dead on the water that for multiple quarters of capital starvation and deteriorating rig counts. While we don't agree with the characterization of the industry being dead, that you may fit non-Tier 1 legacy SCR and mechanical rigs in the U.S. We have long believed Tier 1 AC drive rigs, which constitute nearly 100% of H&P's and 64% of the working industry fleet today, are the relevant rig assets for drilling horizontal wells in the U.S. land segment. After hearing many the comments from this earnings season about the importance of Tier 1 rigs for drilling most efficient horizontal wells, these appears to be the consensus for you today.
Since 2002, our strategy has been designing, building and operating Tier 1 rigs. Over the past 5 years, the industry has gone through on energy renaissance and well complexity has dramatically increased right along with efficiency. H&P has led the way with innovative solutions that have set H&P apart from its peers, particularly in how we have leveraged AC drive technology.
First, by taking ownership, by internalizing expertise in the areas of equipment performance, capital repairs and more practical vertical integration.
Second, providing support services. Our electrical and mechanical staff enable us to leverage knowledge and lifecycle learnings of equipment and our performance groups are proactively engaged in helping our customers to lower total well cost.
Finally, we are committed to a process I will call continuous evolution, where in-house technical resources collaborate with their operational counterparts to enhance existing technology by adding new capability and functionality, as well as leveraging data more effectively to the benefit of those -- of our customers and the company. As in the past, we will continue to invest through the cycles. We have had great success in partnering with customers and moving ideas quickly and to operational deployment. We are developing solutions that will add incremental capacity and/or capability to address market requirements, and we can do this in a scalable and cost-effective way by leveraging our uniform base of existing FlexRig designs to provide value for customers.
We've also taken leadership positions in other areas. Our many first included integrated casing rig services, scripting of wells for enhanced reliability and efficiency, enhance software control capability, integrated sticks lift mitigation and many other technology solutions that today are standard offerings.
The industry has also formed a consensus view that 1,500-horsepower AC drive Tier 1 rigs provide the best drilling performance for drilling the most challenging horizontal wells. H&P's fleet has over 30% of the estimated 700 rigs in the U.S. market today that fit that description. We believe H&P's rigs are strategically placed and ready to mobilize quickly.
Let me use the Permian basin as the example of strategically placed and ready to mobilize quickly. The Permian, by all accounts, is the premier basin in the U.S. and somewhat argued in the top 3 of oil basis in the world. No drilling contractor has a stronger Tier 1 footprint there than H&P. Today, we have a total of 39 FlexRigs on contract in the Permian, more than our top 3 peers combined.
Additionally, we have over 60 idle FlexRigs available with 1,500-horsepower AC drive capability that are ready to work. Let me also make a point for ready to mobilize quickly. We've made prudent investments and taking great care to idle and maintain the FlexRigs properly. Field-tested processes are used to clean and preserve the equipment. In addition, the rigs have been assembled and maintained as needed, so we are ready for the most efficient and cost-effective deployment when the market improves.
For good or bad, H&P's Permian facility has become one of the photographic symbols of this downturn. And as many can see, our FlexRigs are standing tall and ready to go to work.
We often get questions regarding how quickly we can respond to demand with our idle fleet of FlexRigs. We feel very confident we are positioned and better to respond as a result of the investments made in the fleet as described. Whatever the demand might be going forward, we believe we can grow our market share in an improving market as a result of the mentioned characteristics, strategic placement and the ready state of our rig fleet.
In addition to rigs being ready and obvious need and a key advantage in ramping up activity is the availability of quality people. We have done everything in our power to keep our best people clearly in a downturn of this magnitude, it is impossible to keep everyone. Like all companies in the energy sector, we've had to made significant cuts in spending and personnel. It has been very difficult to say goodbye to so many, but we are thankful for having such great people today and look forward to the opportunity of bringing back to work many of those former employees once the cycle turns.
Before turning the call back to Juan Pablo, I want to recognize that in the face of adversity, I've been very pleased with our folks response in dealing with the downturn. Our focus has remained on doing the right things and retaining the right people to enhance our competitive advantages going forward.
Juan Pablo?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John.The company reported $21 million in net income for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. Compensation from customers, corresponding to early termination of long-term contracts, once again allowed us to report quarterly profits. Nevertheless
componenttext:
Thank you, John.
The company reported $21 million in net income for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. Compensation from customers, corresponding to early termination of long-term contracts, once again allowed us to report quarterly profits. Nevertheless, market conditions continued to deteriorate and drilling activity for the company continued to decline.
Following are some comments on each of our drilling segments. Our U.S. land drilling operations generated approximately $63 million in segment operating income during the second fiscal quarter. The number of revenue days declined by approximately 20% as compared to the prior quarter, resulting in an average of close to 106 rigs generating revenue days during the second fiscal quarter. On average, approximately 84 of these rigs were under term contracts and approximately 22 rigs worked in the spot market. In addition to rigs that are no longer contracted and became idle during the quarter, several more rigs became idle that remain under long-term contracts and that are generating revenue days at standby-type day rates, protecting the expected daily cash margin during the term duration of the contracts. This increasing number of rigs was [indiscernible] by top day rates represented approximately 17% of the rigs that were generating revenue days in the segment at the end of the second fiscal quarter.
Excluding the impact of early termination revenues, the average rig revenue per day declined by approximately 1% to $25,931 in the second fiscal quarter and the average rig expense per day increased by approximately 10% to $14,139, resulting in an average rig margin per day of $11,792 in the second fiscal quarter. The increase in the average rig expense per day was primarily attributable to the large number of rigs that became idle during the quarter, generating expenses related to personnel management and rig stacking, which were then allocated across the smaller number of revenue days for the quarter.
It was not a surprise to see our quarter-to-quarter daily expenses increase as we had guided toward $13,600 per day for the quarter. But the increase was higher-than-expected as we experienced some unfavorable volatility during the quarter, related to different type of expenses that we expect will return to more normal levels during the following quarter.
The segment generated approximately $80 million in revenues corresponding to early termination of long-term contracts during the second fiscal quarter. Given existing notifications for early terminations, we expect to generate over $80 million during the third fiscal quarter, about $20 million during the fourth fiscal quarter and over $40 million thereafter in early termination revenues. Nevertheless, about 60% of the mentioned early termination revenues that we expect to be recognized after the second fiscal quarter of 2016 are attributable to compensation that, as of March 31, has already been invoiced and collected and that is included in the current liability section of our March 31, 2016 balance sheet as the deferred revenue. We cannot fully recognize the early termination revenue on a rig until all contractual customer options to pay that rig back to work at full day rates have expired.
Since the peak in late 2014, we have received early termination notifications for a total of 87 rigs under long-term contracts in the segment, up 10 rigs since our last conference call in late January.
Total early termination revenues related to these 87 contracts are now estimated at approximately $460 million, about $88 million of which corresponds to cash flow originally expected to be generated through normal operations during fiscal 2015, $183 million during fiscal 2016 and $189 million after that.
As of today, our 347 available rigs in the U.S. land segment include approximately 84 rigs generating revenue and 263 idle rigs. Included in the 84 rigs generating revenue are 77 rigs under term contracts, 72 of which are generating revenue days. In addition, 7 rigs are currently active in the spot market for a total of 79 rigs generating revenue days in the segment. Nevertheless, approximately 18% of these 79 rigs are now idle and on standby-type day rates reflecting daily cash margins under long-term contracts. Separately, the 5 rigs generating revenue and not generating revenue days include newbuild rigs with deliveries that have been delayed in exchange for compensation from customers.
Looking ahead to the third quarter of fiscal 2016, we expect the decline in the range of 25% to 28% in the number of total revenue days quarter-to-quarter. Excluding the impact of revenues corresponding to early terminated long-term contracts, we expect our average rig revenue per day to decline to approximately $25,000, partly as a result of the relatively high proportion of rigs generating revenue days under standby-type day rates. The average rig expense per day is expected to decrease to roughly $13,800. And these expected decreases is primarily attributable to a greater proportion of rigs on standby-type day rates, which is partly offset by expenses related to the growing proportion of total idle rigs.
Our third fiscal quarter average rig expense per day estimate also includes the impact of a relatively high level of expenses related to a significant ongoing reduction of field personnel positions and employee early retirements.
Absent any additional early terminations and excluding the mentioned rigs for which we have received early termination notifications, the segment currently has term contract commitments in place for an average of approximately 71 rigs during the third fiscal quarter, 69 rigs during the fourth fiscal quarter, 63 rigs during fiscal 2017 and 33 rigs during fiscal 2018. The average daily margins for these rigs that are currently under long-term contracts is expected to remain strong during the next several quarters as some rigs roll off and the remaining newbuilds are deployed.
The average pricing today for the 7 rigs in the spot market remains over 30% lower as compared to the spot pricing at the peak in late 2014.
Let me now transition to our offshore operations. Segment operating income declined to approximately $3 million from $8 million during the prior quarter. Total revenue days declined by about 6% and average rig margin per day declined by about 7% to $7,346 per day during the second fiscal quarter. Most of the rigs that generated revenue during the second fiscal quarter were rigs that remained idle in customer-owned platforms and are generating standby-type day rates.
As we look at the third quarter of fiscal 2016, we expect quarterly revenue days to decline by approximately 8% as 7 of our 9 offshore platform rigs generate revenue days during the quarter. The average rig margin per day is expected to increase to approximately $8,000 during the third fiscal quarter. The expected decline in activity is attributable to a rig that will demobilize and stack onshore during the second fiscal quarter.
Management contracts on platform rigs continued to contribute to our offshore segment operating income. Their contributions during the second fiscal quarter was approximately $2 million. Management contracts are expected to generate approximately $3 million during each of the remaining 2 quarters of fiscal 2016.
Moving on to our international land operations. This segment reported operating losses of approximately $2 million during the second fiscal quarter. The average rig margin per day decreased sequentially from $11,811 to $10,487 per day during the second fiscal quarter. Quarterly revenue days decreased sequentially by approximately 7% to 1,307 days during the same quarter.
As of today, our international then segment has 14 rigs generating revenue days including 10 in Argentina, 2 in the UAE, 1 in Colombia and 1 in Bahrain. All 14 rigs are in their long-term contracts. The 24 remaining rigs are idle.
We expect international land quarterly revenue days to be slightly down by approximately 3% during the third quarter of fiscal 2016 and the average rig margin per day to slightly increase to approximately $11,000 per day.
Let me now comment on corporate level details. Our strong balance sheet and high liquidity position, along with our firm backlog of long-term contracts and reduced CapEx requirements, should continue to allow us to return cash to shareholders by sustaining the level of our regular dividend payments as previously discussed. Excluding rigs with long-term contracts that have already been early terminated and combining all 3 of our drilling segments, we currently have an average of approximately 99 rigs under term contracts expected to be active in fiscal 2016, 78 in fiscal 2017 and 47 in fiscal 2018. Our backlog level as of March 31, 2016, was at approximately $2.3 billion.
Capital expenditures for fiscal 2016 are now expected to be in the range of $300 million to $350 million as compared to our prior guidance of $300 million to $400 million. As mentioned in the past, we expect our total annual depreciation expense for fiscal 2016 to be approximately $580 million and our general and administrative expenses to be approximately $135 million. The effective income tax rate for the second quarter of fiscal 2016 was 32.6%, and we expect the effective tax rate for each of the remaining 2 quarters of fiscal 2016 to be in the range of 33% to 36%. 
With that, let me turn the call back to John.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Juan Pablo.I wanted to mention a couple of comments before we open it up to Q&A. As you know, the U.S. land rig count today is comparable to the all-time record low reached in 1999 and some are comparing the cycle to the 1980s. Even with the
componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo.
I wanted to mention a couple of comments before we open it up to Q&A. As you know, the U.S. land rig count today is comparable to the all-time record low reached in 1999 and some are comparing the cycle to the 1980s. Even with the recent oil price rebound of $45 a barrel, sharp reductions in personnel expenses and investments are continuing worldwide.
With the market intelligence we have today, we expect to see further deterioration in terms of drilling activity during the third fiscal quarter. That said, we are seeing more indications that the bottom of the cycle is nearing. The question remains how quickly E&P companies gain enough confidence in the market to begin investing back into the business and putting idle FlexRigs back to work.
And now Tanishia will open the call for Q&A.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our first question from Dan Boyd with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our first question from Dan Boyd with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the advantages of your rigs and the technology that they have. You also have a number of competitors that are coming out with the latest and greatest rig designs. Just wanted to get your thoughts on, are you looking to come up with a new rig
componenttext: You mentioned the advantages of your rigs and the technology that they have. You also have a number of competitors that are coming out with the latest and greatest rig designs. Just wanted to get your thoughts on, are you looking to come up with a new rig design? And at what point do you think you'll start increasing investments to prepare yourself for the next cycle?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is John. Well, I think if you look at the investments that are being made, first of all, all of those rigs are AC-drive technology. And so that's kind of the basis for the design. And a lot of the design criteria on a lot of the rigs are really
componenttext: Dan, this is John. Well, I think if you look at the investments that are being made, first of all, all of those rigs are AC-drive technology. And so that's kind of the basis for the design. And a lot of the design criteria on a lot of the rigs are really in an effort to match a lot of the rigs that we have out in the field today. So as far as just pure rig designs and I'm speaking primarily to the drilling contractors, I'm not addressing some of the other rig designs out there described as futuristic-type designs, I'm sticking more to the contractors today, we continue to add technology and we have over the past 10-plus years, we've continued to have innovations that improve our systems and we're continually upgrading and high grading. So I sure wouldn't want to leave with you with the impression that we're not looking at other designs and other opportunities. The fact of the matter is, I think, the industry has all of the Tier 1 type rig assets that are needed. The question is, which are those assets are going to work. Obviously, we feel very confident that our rigs are the ones that are going to be most sought after. So we are continuing to invest, but I don't see any real, based on what I've seen, I don't see any real breakthroughs in terms of technologies that are being talked about after.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just to follow-up on putting rigs back to work, there are a lot of moving parts on your daily operating costs. But if you were to add an incremental rig or 10 incremental rigs, what do you think the daily operating costs would be for those specific
componenttext: Okay. Just to follow-up on putting rigs back to work, there are a lot of moving parts on your daily operating costs. But if you were to add an incremental rig or 10 incremental rigs, what do you think the daily operating costs would be for those specific rigs?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think putting out the next 10 rigs, 20 rigs, 30 rigs would be a very low cost for us. The good news for, us obviously, as you would increase your revenue days, so your denominator would increase. I mean, that's part of what's driving our cost up. Cost i
componenttext: I think putting out the next 10 rigs, 20 rigs, 30 rigs would be a very low cost for us. The good news for, us obviously, as you would increase your revenue days, so your denominator would increase. I mean, that's part of what's driving our cost up. Cost in general on rigs that are actually working are very reasonable, it's the other costs that we have associated. So I think the more rigs we can put back to work, the better off we're going to be in terms of our total cost per day.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Angie Sedita with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Angie Sedita with UBS.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, if you think about and we've talked about this before, but maybe if you could elaborate a potential day rate outlook in the U.S. recovery? How you think they could play out? Some drillers are saying that push-per-day rate on the initial rigs are
componenttext: So John, if you think about and we've talked about this before, but maybe if you could elaborate a potential day rate outlook in the U.S. recovery? How you think they could play out? Some drillers are saying that push-per-day rate on the initial rigs are activated. But I think you said in the past that you thought maybe the first 100 rigs could be up flat, day rates to maybe under pressure to some type of share and the second hundred of rig start to see rate playing out. So can you give us any thoughts?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Angie, I think that, that what you described, I think, has some merit. I mean, obviously, ultimately, if you have folks that are pricing in such a fashion that's outside of the norm. But I think in general, what you described make sense. I mean, early on,
componenttext: Angie, I think that, that what you described, I think, has some merit. I mean, obviously, ultimately, if you have folks that are pricing in such a fashion that's outside of the norm. But I think in general, what you described make sense. I mean, early on, I think you're going to see some real pressure on spot market pricing. I mean, as you know, there's not much of a spot market to speak about of right now. There's not a lot of pressure, there's not a lot of bidding going on. But I think the other thing to keep in mind is, in contrast to previous cycles where really every rig out there was out there fighting for that type of work for the more difficult, unconventional horizontal wells, that's a fairly small subset, as you know, of the total rig fleet if you were to look back at the peak of activity in October 2014. So I think the we've described it as around 700 rigs or so, that 1,500-horsepower and, of course, you're going to have a subset of those rigs that are going to the top performers, that have the best equipment. And those are the rigs that are going to be the most sought after.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, in conjunction with that is if you think of that recovery and you noted that a number of your rigs are in this steady-state status. And can you think how quickly you could start to add rigs? Is people going to be a
componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, in conjunction with that is if you think of that recovery and you noted that a number of your rigs are in this steady-state status. And can you think how quickly you could start to add rigs? Is people going to be a bottleneck? And have you had any conversations with your E&Ps on what oil price they would need to come back to the market?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have on the price, and as you know, that price is different for different customers, I think in our last call, we described it as a $45 to $55 range. There's been a few E&Ps, I think, recently that talked about $50. Obviously, there's a lot of co
componenttext: Well, we have on the price, and as you know, that price is different for different customers, I think in our last call, we described it as a $45 to $55 range. There's been a few E&Ps, I think, recently that talked about $50. Obviously, there's a lot of confidence that has to be made up between now and them really beginning to put rigs back to work. But I think that's probably the range that we would need to see in order to see rigs going back to work. As far as our fleet and related to people, we've had great success and past cycles in attracting people back to H&P. We, obviously, have a lot of experience on the rigs that the. So we have all the drillers and all the skill positions we would need to be hiring back more jobs related to floorhand-type work. And again our belief is that once the industry is on a clearer path to recovery, I think you have people that would come back to the industry, but again only time will tell on that.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And 1 more if I can slip it in, that's very helpful. Can you remind us of your FlexRigs and you mentioned 700 of the rigs are 1,500-horsepower, how many of your FlexRigs is 1,500-horsepower?
componenttext: Okay. And 1 more if I can slip it in, that's very helpful. Can you remind us of your FlexRigs and you mentioned 700 of the rigs are 1,500-horsepower, how many of your FlexRigs is 1,500-horsepower?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's over 300, yes, 323. That would be in the U.S. And Angie, I might just also mention, when you look at where the rigs are positioned and talked about the Permian, if you look at our available fleet, the rigs that are idle, we have a little over 30% in
componenttext: It's over 300, yes, 323. That would be in the U.S. And Angie, I might just also mention, when you look at where the rigs are positioned and talked about the Permian, if you look at our available fleet, the rigs that are idle, we have a little over 30% in the Permian, a little over 30% in the Eagle Ford. And so those are, from my perspective, 2 of the lower cost basins that you would expect to see rigs going back to work. So we're positioned really well from that standpoint.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And for you guys are the leading market share in both of those basins, correct?
componenttext: Okay. And for you guys are the leading market share in both of those basins, correct?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016

componenttext: I wanted to see if I can get a little bit more color on the CapEx reduction. Are you guys seeing greater efficiencies on the maintenance CapEx side? componenttextpreview: Sure, Matt, this is Juan Pablo. As we have described in the past, a lot of the $300 million to $400 million of dollars that we previously estimated were related to market conditions. And, obviously, market conditions have been soft even softer-than-expect
componenttext: Sure, Matt, this is Juan Pablo. As we have described in the past, a lot of the $300 million to $400 million of dollars that we previously estimated were related to market conditions. And, obviously, market conditions have been soft even softer-than-expected and expect it to remain relatively soft. And that is driving down some of the maintenance CapEx and also some of the special projects that would be in response to a potentially improving market.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's mostly based on market conditions.
componenttext: So it's mostly based on market conditions.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, there hasn't been a major structural change in kind of a run rate maintenance CapEx as we think about a per rig basis, we shouldn't think of there being a permanent change in there, right?
componenttext: So I guess, there hasn't been a major structural change in kind of a run rate maintenance CapEx as we think about a per rig basis, we shouldn't think of there being a permanent change in there, right?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really, it's not perfect process, of course. Maintenance CapEx depends on a lot of considerations. One important one is what rigs we have working, if you have mostly newbuild working, newbuild rigs working or rigs that have been built in recent years,
componenttext: Not really, it's not perfect process, of course. Maintenance CapEx depends on a lot of considerations. One important one is what rigs we have working, if you have mostly newbuild working, newbuild rigs working or rigs that have been built in recent years, then your maintenance CapEx will probably be lower and that's part of what we're seeing out there. The other consideration relates to a lot of components being available and the existing fleet that we're trying to be as efficient as we can and using that, of course, before seeing any deterioration in the field for the lack of use.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate the color. And then my next question here really switching to the international fleet. Can you may be help us see the long-term goal internationally? Can you continue to use South America, for example, as kind of a relief valve as it relates to
componenttext: Appreciate the color. And then my next question here really switching to the international fleet. Can you may be help us see the long-term goal internationally? Can you continue to use South America, for example, as kind of a relief valve as it relates to put clearly an oversaturated U.S. land complex? And maybe talk about the appetite for a Tier 1 rigs internationally? Do you see that changing and evolving? I recall you're able to send, I think it was 10, 12 rigs down to South America recently over the last couple of years. But what other opportunities do you see? Can you maybe expand more in the Eastern Hemisphere? As you look at international rigs, a lot of it is South America. How can we view the kind of international business for H&P in the longer term do you think?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is John. And we've talked about this for years. And you're right, we did have -- we did send 10 existing FlexRig3s to Argentina a few years ago now. And we have Flex 3s in Colombia as well as Flex4s both in Colombia and Argentina. And we have F
componenttext: Matt, this is John. And we've talked about this for years. And you're right, we did have -- we did send 10 existing FlexRig3s to Argentina a few years ago now. And we have Flex 3s in Colombia as well as Flex4s both in Colombia and Argentina. And we have Flex 3s and Flex 4s in the Middle East. We've thought for a long time that we can have some significant growth internationally. As you know, international markets are struggling right now as well. But we do see the current fleet that we have in the U.S. being able to expand internationally with those opportunities arise. We keep thinking that it will be growth in the international area in terms of unconventional resource plays, and really that's what the 10 rigs, the growth in Argentina for the Flex 3, that's what that was all about. And so hopefully, we'll see that happen. I think there's nobody better position in H&P to take advantage of that. As you know, we've been working internationally for over 50 years so we have a lot of experience and capabilities. So we're just waiting for those opportunities.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. And do you think as you look at to the Middle East maybe an area where you could deploy more assets? Is there a hunger for more rig contractors to enter into the market? Or can you maybe help us understand the competitive landscape, how
componenttext: I appreciate that. And do you think as you look at to the Middle East maybe an area where you could deploy more assets? Is there a hunger for more rig contractors to enter into the market? Or can you maybe help us understand the competitive landscape, how difficult it is to break it to certain territories, I guess, in the greater scale if you're already there is kind of my last question and I'll hope back in the queue.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I do think there's any doubt that having a footprint there is advantageous. We've got a couple of FlexRigs in UAE and we have Flex 4s in Bahrain. So we have some opportunity to expand. Again we're looking forward to that, we just don't have an
componenttext: Sure. Well, I do think there's any doubt that having a footprint there is advantageous. We've got a couple of FlexRigs in UAE and we have Flex 4s in Bahrain. So we have some opportunity to expand. Again we're looking forward to that, we just don't have anything really in our sights right now in terms of opportunities. But we believe that there will be opportunities in the future.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Marc Bianchi with Cowen.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Marc Bianchi with Cowen.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the guidance here for the upcoming quarter, it seems like the proportion of rigs on long-term contract is going to be pretty high as a proportion of the total rigs working. And then looking at the margin guidance, you have margins going do
componenttext: Just looking at the guidance here for the upcoming quarter, it seems like the proportion of rigs on long-term contract is going to be pretty high as a proportion of the total rigs working. And then looking at the margin guidance, you have margins going down. I would have thought that margins would move higher if you have a larger proportion, being long-term contract. Can you speak to that, please?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mark, this is Juan Pablo. At least there's a couple of things that are contributing to an unfavorable move. And the first one has to do with a growing proportion of idle rigs and expenses associated with those idle rigs. Some of those expenses are f
componenttext: Sure, Mark, this is Juan Pablo. At least there's a couple of things that are contributing to an unfavorable move. And the first one has to do with a growing proportion of idle rigs and expenses associated with those idle rigs. Some of those expenses are fixed, some relate to the process that we are going through. The transition as rig become idle, as you know, there are stacking expenses, there are personnel expenses that we incur and so that impacts the average unfavorably. We also have a couple of other things going on. One is related to a higher-than-normal number of personnel positions in the field and early retirements related to employees. So that's what is impacting the average rig margin, the 13,800 that we guided toward and the way that is unfavorable. Hopefully as John mentioned, as we have the seeing more stability and, hopefully, see rigs going back to the field, we hope to have a favorable movement in the average rig expense per day.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there anything that's, you mentioned the personnel cost there that maybe perhaps one time, is there any piece of this that we can think of as one time in your fiscal third that wouldn't be in the fourth?
componenttext: Is there anything that's, you mentioned the personnel cost there that maybe perhaps one time, is there any piece of this that we can think of as one time in your fiscal third that wouldn't be in the fourth?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it all depends on what level of transition we see in the fourth fiscal quarter. Obviously, when we have transitions like these, all of those expenses, we believe, are specific to the quarter and, hopefully, are nonrecurring. But fortunately, we've b
componenttext: Well, it all depends on what level of transition we see in the fourth fiscal quarter. Obviously, when we have transitions like these, all of those expenses, we believe, are specific to the quarter and, hopefully, are nonrecurring. But fortunately, we've been going through this quarter-after-quarter. During the third fiscal quarter, we expect a very significant decline as mentioned of 25% to 28%. And when they that happens, those expenses that pertain the quarter and all those moving variables that are not normal, that are ongoing, that's really what's. And going forward, we -- hold on just a second, please. I have one clarification, I may have related to our margin guidance of 13 8, I was referring to the average rig expense being 13 8, of course, as we spoke earlier about. But let me stop there, does that answer your question, Mark?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's helpful, Juan Pablo. I guess, maybe related is, has there been any adjustment in any of the contracted rates that you have?
componenttext: Yes. That's helpful, Juan Pablo. I guess, maybe related is, has there been any adjustment in any of the contracted rates that you have?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not significant. As we mentioned these -- some of these rigs are being -- are becoming idle and we are charging day rates that protect us in terms of expected margins for those rigs. But nothing significant that's going on in terms of what we expect to, I
componenttext: Not significant. As we mentioned these -- some of these rigs are being -- are becoming idle and we are charging day rates that protect us in terms of expected margins for those rigs. But nothing significant that's going on in terms of what we expect to, I think, from our long-term contracts.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Mark, this is John. I wanted to also clarify, make certain that the guys in the field have really done an excellent job. We talked about it on the last call related to expenses and really managing that in a really strong way. So this cost increase re
componenttext: And, Mark, this is John. I wanted to also clarify, make certain that the guys in the field have really done an excellent job. We talked about it on the last call related to expenses and really managing that in a really strong way. So this cost increase really has nothing to do with the rig itself, as I have mentioned before. We were leadership teams in the Permian basin a couple of weeks ago. And it was really impressive to see how hard they're working and the attitude that they have in this market. But when you consider all the things that Juan Pablo had addressed, that's really what's driving the cost, it's not the actual expenses at the rig site.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. If I could just one more for, Juan Pablo. On the depreciation, been running a little bit lower than the guidance that you provided for the year. Is there any reason to think that on a quarterly basis, it's going to tick up here in the back h
componenttext: Got it, okay. If I could just one more for, Juan Pablo. On the depreciation, been running a little bit lower than the guidance that you provided for the year. Is there any reason to think that on a quarterly basis, it's going to tick up here in the back half?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It may. There are some variables that impact that. Hopefully, we'll see a number for the year that is lower than the 5 80. But we don't have enough information and certainty at this point to provide that guidance. We may update the guidance, of course, du
componenttext: It may. There are some variables that impact that. Hopefully, we'll see a number for the year that is lower than the 5 80. But we don't have enough information and certainty at this point to provide that guidance. We may update the guidance, of course, during our next conference call.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go ahead and take our next question from Daniel John with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And we'll go ahead and take our next question from Daniel John with Simmons & Company.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things for you. First question, just based on inbound inquiries from clients. Do you believe that revenue days will increase in the fourth fiscal quarter over the current quarter?
componenttext: A couple of things for you. First question, just based on inbound inquiries from clients. Do you believe that revenue days will increase in the fourth fiscal quarter over the current quarter?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, there's not a lot of -- unfortunately, there's not a lot of inbound calls. And I think if we were to make an answer based on a hunch, if oil prices would remain $45 plus and I think you could see some confidence in the market, I think you could begi
componenttext: John, there's not a lot of -- unfortunately, there's not a lot of inbound calls. And I think if we were to make an answer based on a hunch, if oil prices would remain $45 plus and I think you could see some confidence in the market, I think you could begin to potentially see some rigs go back to work. But as you know, as we all suffered through witness in the last summer, when oil prices were in the $55 to $60 range and then pulled back. And so I think, it's is going to have to maintain a level of consistency for some period of time before you see rigs going back to work. But I mean, I wouldn't be surprised to see rigs going back in the fourth quarter. But at this stage of the game, we're sure not receiving a lot of calls.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. Because you did mention, I think, the fiscal Q3 cost-per-day guidance does include some [indiscernible] cost. So it seemed to me that you're not expecting a sharp recovery at this point, a quick recovery.
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. Because you did mention, I think, the fiscal Q3 cost-per-day guidance does include some [indiscernible] cost. So it seemed to me that you're not expecting a sharp recovery at this point, a quick recovery.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Based on what we see right now for the third quarter, we don't see any recovery. Obviously, it can happen, it could be ongoing right now. And if you know it would begin by one way to think about it is rigs that have been given notification of release, tho
componenttext: Based on what we see right now for the third quarter, we don't see any recovery. Obviously, it can happen, it could be ongoing right now. And if you know it would begin by one way to think about it is rigs that have been given notification of release, those notifications get rescinded and rigs don't actually get released and rigs that are on standby would go back to work and then, ultimately, you begin to see some rigs being picked up in the spot market. So that could happen. We just haven't seen it begin at this stage.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. Just one final one for me, I'll turn it over. Just trying to better understand the whole impact of drilling efficiencies and how that will impact the recovery in the rig count. So just on that point, when you visit customers and they share yo
componenttext: Fair enough. Just one final one for me, I'll turn it over. Just trying to better understand the whole impact of drilling efficiencies and how that will impact the recovery in the rig count. So just on that point, when you visit customers and they share you their rig count needs going forward, assume on a higher commodity price deck. Do they provide any color to you about what their peak potential rig count may be? And if so, how does that compare with what they have been in the most recent peak rig count?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I think -- well, it is a hard one. And I think one of the reasons why it's so hard is because I mean, that's really probably one of the last things anybody's really thinking about right now because they've been cutting their rig counts and trying to
componenttext: John, I think -- well, it is a hard one. And I think one of the reasons why it's so hard is because I mean, that's really probably one of the last things anybody's really thinking about right now because they've been cutting their rig counts and trying to figure out how to right size their organization. And I think anybody's really thinking about of those types of comparisons. I think longer-term, I personally don't think it's as dramatic as a lot of people believe. But again only time is going to tell. I sure don't expect to see 1,800 rigs working anytime soon. But yes, we just haven't heard anything from customers on that point.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Michael Lamont with Guggenheim.

componenttext: Maybe I can start with the side of the inverse of Angie's question, which is how much of the fleet today is 1,000-horsepower?

componenttext: We'll take a look at it.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And with all the emphasis on the 1,500, what is the outlook for the 1,000?
componenttext: Okay. And with all the emphasis on the 1,500, what is the outlook for the 1,000?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have around 22 rigs that are 1,000 horse. Those rigs are typically designed for more vertical, shallower-type work. We actually have that particular model of Flex 4 working in Colombia and Argentina and in the Middle East. Actually I'm not cert
componenttext: I think we have around 22 rigs that are 1,000 horse. Those rigs are typically designed for more vertical, shallower-type work. We actually have that particular model of Flex 4 working in Colombia and Argentina and in the Middle East. Actually I'm not certain on the ones that are working in Argentina right now. But in any event, we have those rigs. So those rigs are candidates to work internationally. They're, obviously, candidates to go back to work in the Permian basin because that's where most, if not all of those rigs, are going for vertical type work, not for horizontal work.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's no real risk of impairment to those at this point?
componenttext: So there's no real risk of impairment to those at this point?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I sure don't think so. Again, those rigs have work recently and I think that, that vertical, that 8,000 to 12,000-foot vertical type work in some of the basins in the U.S. and as well as internationally are going to be in existence.
componenttext: I sure don't think so. Again, those rigs have work recently and I think that, that vertical, that 8,000 to 12,000-foot vertical type work in some of the basins in the U.S. and as well as internationally are going to be in existence.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. On reactivations, glad to see you in terms of term, make sure I going to have to go out and [indiscernible] and spend some money to gear up, I imagine you're not going to do that for a well-type work.
componenttext: Okay. On reactivations, glad to see you in terms of term, make sure I going to have to go out and [indiscernible] and spend some money to gear up, I imagine you're not going to do that for a well-type work.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, I think for anybody to expect that you're going to get work term contract work coming off a lot in this environment, I think that would be a surprise. Again in order for us to activate a rig and get it out working is going to be very, very
componenttext: Well, Michael, I think for anybody to expect that you're going to get work term contract work coming off a lot in this environment, I think that would be a surprise. Again in order for us to activate a rig and get it out working is going to be very, very low cost for us. We're well prepared, acquiring the personnel that's not a high cost. So I don't see that as being a stretch. And we won't be going in more than likely, you're not going to just do 1 well, I mean, unless the quality environment were to begin to pull back again, you're going to drill multiple wells. So I'd be surprised to see many of these rigs going back to work with term contract commitments.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the decision to reactivate really is a function of nothing else and immediately available and you don't want to say, no, to a client?
componenttext: So the decision to reactivate really is a function of nothing else and immediately available and you don't want to say, no, to a client?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's in our best interest to get rigs back working for a lot of reasons related to people and revenue days and as Juan Pablo described, I mean, that's part of the challenge we have related to expenses is a larger numerator in a smaller denominator.
componenttext: Well, it's in our best interest to get rigs back working for a lot of reasons related to people and revenue days and as Juan Pablo described, I mean, that's part of the challenge we have related to expenses is a larger numerator in a smaller denominator. So if we can put rigs back to work, that's beneficial for us and beneficial for customers, beneficial for our employees.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: For sure. I understand that I just made the decision to activate or weather, it's really customer-driven or are you anticipating customer activity?
componenttext: For sure. I understand that I just made the decision to activate or weather, it's really customer-driven or are you anticipating customer activity?

componenttext: Well, yes, and we have as you know, really long-term relationships with some really strong customers that would probably be some of those that would respond what quickly than others. So we're going to be there for them and be ready to response.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Robin Shoemaker with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to -- most of my questions have been answered. But I wanted to ask you about the status of the facility that you have in Houston, which -- where you assemble and refurbish rigs. And just some of the way it looks, I think you had a little bit of a
componenttext: I wanted to -- most of my questions have been answered. But I wanted to ask you about the status of the facility that you have in Houston, which -- where you assemble and refurbish rigs. And just some of the way it looks, I think you had a little bit of a backlog of maybe 3 or 4 rigs to be yet to be built that you've deferred. But what role might that play in going forward? It seems like it would be a long time before you would actually build another rig or even refurbished since you've got some very new rigs, right, ready to go?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robin, this is John. The facility, you're right, don't expect to be building any new rigs anytime soon. We have utilized that facility, you touched on refurbishing, we have utilized that facility to refurbish rigs, getting them ready for international wor
componenttext: Robin, this is John. The facility, you're right, don't expect to be building any new rigs anytime soon. We have utilized that facility, you touched on refurbishing, we have utilized that facility to refurbish rigs, getting them ready for international work. And we've also used that facility for certain upgrades that we've done to our rig fleet. And so that's part of the way that, up to this point, in addition to finishing out those new builds that we've been able to keep some folks employed. But obviously, it's got -- it's not going to be turning out the amount of material that it did before. So but we'll continue to keep an eye on that. But that's how we do utilize that facility and other facilities just to upgrade and high grade the fleet.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And was the remaining kind of backlog of new builds that you had, has that been switched to like existing rigs that are available or?
componenttext: And was the remaining kind of backlog of new builds that you had, has that been switched to like existing rigs that are available or?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robin, this is Juan Pablo. We have a couple of 3 rigs that are pending delivery. So those are the construction for those is ongoing and we expect that to be completed this year. But as John said, other than that, meaning other than the rigs that already h
componenttext: Robin, this is Juan Pablo. We have a couple of 3 rigs that are pending delivery. So those are the construction for those is ongoing and we expect that to be completed this year. But as John said, other than that, meaning other than the rigs that already have long-term contracts associated with them, there are no plans for other newbuilds at this point.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016

componenttext: Juan Pablo, just to clarify on the CapEx. The delayed newbuilds, how much of that is included? componenttext: So if you've got newbuilds that have been competed, but have not been delayed, I mean, not been delivered and are going to be delayed for whatever period of time, are those depreciating?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Yes, we typically depreciate our rigs ones they spud operations. And so the delayed rigs have not yet begun depreciation from a financial perspective. And so, obviously, that's impacting the depreciation number in a slightly favorable way, maki
componenttext: Thank you. Yes, we typically depreciate our rigs ones they spud operations. And so the delayed rigs have not yet begun depreciation from a financial perspective. And so, obviously, that's impacting the depreciation number in a slightly favorable way, making it slightly lower-than-expected. But the impact is not very significant given the scale of our total depreciation.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one more on this line of questioning, are you continuing to upgrade your idle rigs? And if so, what are you including in these upgrades? Is it to the extent you're doing it? Is it still just adding skidding system still FlexRigs that don't
componenttext: Okay. And then one more on this line of questioning, are you continuing to upgrade your idle rigs? And if so, what are you including in these upgrades? Is it to the extent you're doing it? Is it still just adding skidding system still FlexRigs that don't have them? Or have you now also started to add third mud pumps and where possible, upgrade the psi capability?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tom, we have -- we've continued to upgrade the fleet to 7,500 on those that have 5,000 when the customer needs it. We've added third mud pumps, we've added fourth engines, we've increased setback capacity on the rigs in order to handle -- a lot of th
componenttext: Yes, Tom, we have -- we've continued to upgrade the fleet to 7,500 on those that have 5,000 when the customer needs it. We've added third mud pumps, we've added fourth engines, we've increased setback capacity on the rigs in order to handle -- a lot of the rigs already have the capacity for 25,000 foot of setback, but not all of them to. So with various, I kind of addressed a little bit of that in my prepared remarks that we've continued to do that over time. And we're doing that in this cycle as well.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is around with margins and the progression that make it in the recovery area. And as you said that spot day rates peak are around 30%. You said over the course of the call, that most of the rigs will go to work at least in the recovery from sp
componenttext: My question is around with margins and the progression that make it in the recovery area. And as you said that spot day rates peak are around 30%. You said over the course of the call, that most of the rigs will go to work at least in the recovery from spot. So I'd you think about that, that seems to tell me that even as you recover your day rates -- your average margin come down, I guess, the question really lies into, A, calibrating that. But B, being about what absorption offset is from a fixed cost perspective. And just how to calibrate it I'd realize you guys have taken a fairly conservative tact on the call, just trying to get a sensitivity thought process on how to think about that on my model.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Darren, this is Juan Pablo. There are so many moving pieces there that we have to take there that I would hesitate to start outlining those because there's not just 1 or 2 that I could mention that, that would bring clarity to that. I think your overall a
componenttext: Darren, this is Juan Pablo. There are so many moving pieces there that we have to take there that I would hesitate to start outlining those because there's not just 1 or 2 that I could mention that, that would bring clarity to that. I think your overall assumption is true. Obviously, if we enter a recovery and we put the rigs back to work, those rigs will probably go back to work at day rates and margins that relates closely to where we are in the spot market today. And as that happens, the impact of that will be probably negative on the margin as we have a higher proportion of rigs in the spot market going forward assuming, of course, that we have recovery. The only other factor that I'll mention is what John already mentioned and that is, that as we put rigs back to work and total number of idle rigs begins to decline, that in general will have a favorable impact on margins as some of those fixed costs related to the idle fleet will start to be reabsorbed. But I'm sorry, not to be able to provide more clarity but, hopefully, that helps.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not as a simple straightforward way, Darren. I think pricing will depend -- the average rig revenue per day will be impacted by any -- by the proportion of rigs that are on standby and that have a significantly lower day rates as we don't have the rigs wo
componenttext: Not as a simple straightforward way, Darren. I think pricing will depend -- the average rig revenue per day will be impacted by any -- by the proportion of rigs that are on standby and that have a significantly lower day rates as we don't have the rigs working and what proportion that makes up in terms of the total. But that one more moving piece as we go forward. I think what may be an important part of the question is, related to the rigs that we already have under term contracts and what those margins might be. And the answer to that is that the margins, the rigs that are on term contracts that are currently operating or that are on standby-type day rates, those are as strong as we expected. We have not seen any deterioration in there as expected. Obviously, we benefited from early terminations and vary significantly. And so our backlog is a very important piece of the equation for us, and it has been strong and we expect for that to continue to be strong. But other expenses related to transition area expenses, related to all of the aspects that we've already mentioned our also an important part of the equation. And now we'll turn it back to John Lindsay for some closing remarks.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you again for listening this morning. I'm going to close by leaving you with the following thoughts: In that our long-term contracts have allowed the company to remain profitable and to protect FlexRig investments. The company's efforts in energy
componenttext:
So thank you again for listening this morning. I'm going to close by leaving you with the following thoughts: In that our long-term contracts have allowed the company to remain profitable and to protect FlexRig investments. The company's efforts in energy are focused on adding value to our customers and becoming even more efficient and effective us on organization. But as we see more declines and activity or significant improvement in demand, H&P is well-positioned to respond.
As we have described in the past, our strong and liquid balance sheet, robust backlog and lower spending requirements should allow us to continue to return cash to shareholders. Our strength is driven by our people and we appreciate their attitude in the face of this adversity and their dedication to the company through this difficult times.
And again, thank you for listening in with us this morning and have a great day.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that does conclude today's program. We'd like to thank you for your participation. Have a wonderful day and you may disconnect at any time.
componenttext: And that does conclude today's program. We'd like to thank you for your participation. Have a wonderful day and you may disconnect at any time.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 02, 2016
