componenttextpreview: If we were to use a base Flex3 that didn't already have a pad system, then it would be to add 7,500 in the pad system would be approximately $2 million.
componenttext: If we were to use a base Flex3 that didn't already have a pad system, then it would be to add 7,500 in the pad system would be approximately $2 million.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we already have the -- which there are Flex3s that are idle that have the pad application, a skid system that are idle. So there's several that we will just upgrade with just the 7,500. And then there's also some, in some cases, we're upgrading the set
componenttext: If we already have the -- which there are Flex3s that are idle that have the pad application, a skid system that are idle. So there's several that we will just upgrade with just the 7,500. And then there's also some, in some cases, we're upgrading the setback capacity. That's a relatively small investment. I want to say it's around $200,000-or-so. There's some folks that include, in a super-spec, the third and the fourth engine. The way we've approached it, Michael, is it's really on need basis. If the customer has a true need for the third pump or the fourth engine, if the hydraulics requirements are there, then that's what we're doing. But it really depends on basin and it's really dependent customer to customer whether you need 2 or whether you need 3. And that's a relatively small incremental investment. Obviously, was already own the pumps and the engines, it's just rated the installation cost, the rigs are set up and designed to accept the additional equipment.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And about how much time, if you're doing the full $2 million, how much time do you need to get all that work done?
componenttext: Okay. And about how much time, if you're doing the full $2 million, how much time do you need to get all that work done?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of it, as you can imagine, is kind of like asking us a question how long does it take to build the FlexRig because a lot of the work is being done offline. If you're doing the work on a rig, on drilling a rig move, which happens occasionally,
componenttext: Well, a lot of it, as you can imagine, is kind of like asking us a question how long does it take to build the FlexRig because a lot of the work is being done offline. If you're doing the work on a rig, on drilling a rig move, which happens occasionally, you're talking about a couple of extra days. If it's being done on a rig that has been idle, again, it doesn't take very long. A lot of the manufacturing, the fabrication is being done offline in our facilities similar to -- or in the facilities that we've used to build rigs in the past. So as you can imagine, it's being done offline. The fleet profile is uniform, so it's kind of a lean manufacturing effort, if you will. So it's kind of hard to say how long it takes for a rig that's idle, it really doesn't make any difference because it's being done offline. During a rig move, I want to say it's 2 to 4 days. I don't remember exactly, but I think that's right.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The important thing is it's not a month, it really is pretty quick. And then last one for me. On those super-specs, just in terms of the increase that you're getting as you sort of look forward into the demand, is it a third of the incremental inqui
componenttext: Okay. The important thing is it's not a month, it really is pretty quick. And then last one for me. On those super-specs, just in terms of the increase that you're getting as you sort of look forward into the demand, is it a third of the incremental inquiry half? What's roughly the mix in terms of what customers are coming to you for today?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a great question. I wish I would have thought about that and have the answer for you. I'll think about looking at our market lines. Surprisingly enough, we still have -- I'd say surprising because there's so much focus on super-spec. We still have
componenttext: That is a great question. I wish I would have thought about that and have the answer for you. I'll think about looking at our market lines. Surprisingly enough, we still have -- I'd say surprising because there's so much focus on super-spec. We still have customers that are still  their requirement, their need base is FlexRig3, some are single well, some are pad with slightly 2 pumps and 5,000-psi. If I were to guess, I'd say it's anywhere from half to 75% is kind of what I would estimate today. We made a note in our comments that for the rigs, the 32 rigs that we reactivated, 75% of those were super-spec, were with pad and 7,500-psi. And again, to be clear, some of those 7,500 had 2 pumps and some had 3. And again, it's based upon what the customers' needs are.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll mode to Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, I know there's a lot of different semantics laying around the marketplace in terms of super-spec and, obviously, one of your larger competitors over the last couple of weeks had an Analyst Day and talked about some additional technology that they
componenttext: So John, I know there's a lot of different semantics laying around the marketplace in terms of super-spec and, obviously, one of your larger competitors over the last couple of weeks had an Analyst Day and talked about some additional technology that they were adding to the mix. By focusing on the super-spec, as you referenced it and focusing on that term pad optimal, does that pad optimal include walking system or is that just your current skid system?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: The pad optimal or pad capability, whatever you call it, is still as we've described, our skid systems for Flex3s and Flex5s. Of course, Flex4s were designed with skid capability, pad capability as well. So that is the design and I mean, you know because
componenttext: The pad optimal or pad capability, whatever you call it, is still as we've described, our skid systems for Flex3s and Flex5s. Of course, Flex4s were designed with skid capability, pad capability as well. So that is the design and I mean, you know because we've talked about it several times. And quite frankly, we've been talking about it for a couple of years now, that when we have the demand from a customer in a meaningful way then that's something that we will do, we can do. We've had have designs for it. And so I'm sure eventually we will do that. But at this stage of the game, what we've described in our fleet are Flex3s and Flex5s in the traditional pad configuration.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess we would take away from your commentary today that, again, the vast majority of the customer base is not asking for omnidirectional walking rig capability?
componenttext: And then I guess we would take away from your commentary today that, again, the vast majority of the customer base is not asking for omnidirectional walking rig capability?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do have -- when you say omnidirectional, we do have omnidirectional capability with Flex4s and Flex5s, but typically that decent the need. And so in the Flex5 -- I'm sorry, the Flex3, if you go back long enough, the initial pads were relatively s
componenttext: Well, we do have -- when you say omnidirectional, we do have omnidirectional capability with Flex4s and Flex5s, but typically that decent the need. And so in the Flex5 -- I'm sorry, the Flex3, if you go back long enough, the initial pads were relatively small, they were 50 to 75 feet. And we have Flex3s today that are actually on 200-foot skid applications that were great. So the omnidirectional portion, the demand we've been able to meet with Flex5s or Flex4s where we needed it and it really has an impact in our customer's designs as far as using the FlexRig3.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Great. And then maybe just one more follow-up on the incremental demand. You mentioned additional rigs in a number of different basins. Clearly, the vast majority being in the Permian. What have you been taking up recently in discussion with E&
componenttext: All right. Great. And then maybe just one more follow-up on the incremental demand. You mentioned additional rigs in a number of different basins. Clearly, the vast majority being in the Permian. What have you been taking up recently in discussion with E&P customers with respect to increased activity in Eagle Ford or the Bakken, obviously, you mentioned the Haynesville so that kind of captured my attention as well. So outside of the Permian, what were you hearing?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think my sense would be it seems like Eagle Ford compared to the last several months, there have been more inquiries in the Eagle Ford than what we've seen, which is obviously great news for us if we can see some material increases, because that was our
componenttext: I think my sense would be it seems like Eagle Ford compared to the last several months, there have been more inquiries in the Eagle Ford than what we've seen, which is obviously great news for us if we can see some material increases, because that was our second largest operational area back at the peak. We have great rigs and people and we're set up very well there. As I think about it, David, I don't know. My sense would be we continue to have demand kind of across the board like it has been. I mean, I look back on this quarter and then the previous quarter and the Permian continue to be just under half and then the other ones are pretty equally distributed.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's fair, John.
componenttext: I think it's fair, John.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's just nothing that jumps off the page and says, yes, this is the area. Maybe with the exception of the Eagle Ford, we have had some or at least it seems like some additional discussions.
componenttext: There's just nothing that jumps off the page and says, yes, this is the area. Maybe with the exception of the Eagle Ford, we have had some or at least it seems like some additional discussions.

componenttext: Okay. And is there any -- are there any common elements to those contracts or they're all very customer-specific. And what are rate escalators, what actually gets you more rate as we move out in time on those contracts?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, on the term contracts, it's a true term contract where it's a fix rate, it has cost escalators if we had some sort of an increase, wage increase or something, we have cost escalation provisions. But in general, it's a fixed rate or maybe th
componenttext: Well, Michael, on the term contracts, it's a true term contract where it's a fix rate, it has cost escalators if we had some sort of an increase, wage increase or something, we have cost escalation provisions. But in general, it's a fixed rate or maybe the way to think about it is it's a fix margin for us. Again, we've talked about it over the last several months. We're not going to be entering into very many of those. Obviously, we have in this particular case. Most of what we're going to be doing is just what you've seen, which is spot market contracts and spot market pricing.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the field labor, where are we today relative to peak in 2014 in terms of wages?
componenttext: Okay. And on the field labor, where are we today relative to peak in 2014 in terms of wages?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're at the same level. Our wages are at the same level today as they were in 2014.
componenttext: We're at the same level. Our wages are at the same level today as they were in 2014.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is there any pressure on those as you are out rehiring folks?
componenttext: Okay. And is there any pressure on those as you are out rehiring folks?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't get a sense that there's pressure. I think one of the things to consider is that, I mentioned it in my comments, workforce staffing is doing a great job and we're all having great success in hiring former employees back that were laid off during t
componenttext: I don't get a sense that there's pressure. I think one of the things to consider is that, I mentioned it in my comments, workforce staffing is doing a great job and we're all having great success in hiring former employees back that were laid off during the downturn. And they're coming back to work. And so what that's creating is they're coming into the entry level positions and now it's a great opportunity to move back into the drillers position and driller back into rig manager position or even promoting a few superintendents up into the position. So there increases that are going on, going on in the organization, but it's of option a been promoted to a higher-level position. I would be surprised that there would be wage pressure, at least for the foreseeable future, and it's kind of hard to get your arms around. We haven't predicted what the rig count is going, but I don't see that on the horizon right now.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Robin Shoemaker with Keybank Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Robin Shoemaker with Keybank Capital Markets.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, I wanted to ask about on the super-spec rigs. What is sort of the pipe racking capacity that goes with that kind of asset?
componenttext: So John, I wanted to ask about on the super-spec rigs. What is sort of the pipe racking capacity that goes with that kind of asset?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- again, it comes back to definition. We have the standard FlexRig3, which was 22,000 to 23,000 fleet. We're upgrading it to a 25,000 to 26,000-foot range. But we're only doing that upgrade if you're drilling 18,000, 20,000-foot wells. Obvi
componenttext: Well, we have -- again, it comes back to definition. We have the standard FlexRig3, which was 22,000 to 23,000 fleet. We're upgrading it to a 25,000 to 26,000-foot range. But we're only doing that upgrade if you're drilling 18,000, 20,000-foot wells. Obviously, by definition you don't need that additional setback capacity. Flex 5s came out standard with 25,000 or 26,000-foot setback capacity. I believe I got that right. So it's really rubbing in response to what the customers' needs are. We have that capability with a pretty low-cost investment of extending that setback capacity 25,000 to 26,000 peak.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I had another question, unrelated. We've been hearing from other drilling contractors and service companies about quite a bit of tendering activity for land rigs in the Middle East, multiple countries. And I wonder if you could comment on that and y
componenttext: Okay. I had another question, unrelated. We've been hearing from other drilling contractors and service companies about quite a bit of tendering activity for land rigs in the Middle East, multiple countries. And I wonder if you could comment on that and your level of interest in those tenders, are they the type of rigs? Are they for FlexRigs, are they the type of rig tenders for which your rigs are suited?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there have been some tenders. I don't remember all the details. We have a bid Flex 3s on international projects. I think we've also possibly even bid on some 3,000-horsepower work, which obviously we have 3,000-horsepower SCR rigs as well. So we have
componenttext: Yes, there have been some tenders. I don't remember all the details. We have a bid Flex 3s on international projects. I think we've also possibly even bid on some 3,000-horsepower work, which obviously we have 3,000-horsepower SCR rigs as well. So we have participated or at least on the front-end of participating. As far as I know we haven't heard anything back. I think it's still in the early stages at this stage.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, on -- you mentioned at one point that in the U.S. spot -- average spot rates have come up a little bit from the lowest point. And I wonder if you could -- should we characterize that as a couple of thousand dollars a day or is there som
componenttext: Okay. And finally, on -- you mentioned at one point that in the U.S. spot -- average spot rates have come up a little bit from the lowest point. And I wonder if you could -- should we characterize that as a couple of thousand dollars a day or is there some way you can frame that for us?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they have, again, I think if you go back to our call in July and even some of the conferences that we've been at, we've talked about, there would be a lot of competition coming off the bottom. Kind of looking back in hindsight, you can see that May
componenttext: Well, they have, again, I think if you go back to our call in July and even some of the conferences that we've been at, we've talked about, there would be a lot of competition coming off the bottom. Kind of looking back in hindsight, you can see that May was the trough. And I think our lowest pricing was in August. And so we're starting to see some improvements. I think to generally categorize $1,000 to $2,000 a day is a fine categorization, again depending on the area, depending on the customer, depending on a lot of things. But that's about all the clarity that I think we're willing to talk about at this stage. But I don't think there's any doubt that for high-quality rigs and high-quality performance, our expectation is that they'll start to become some pricing power in the market.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Marc Bianchi with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Marc Bianchi with Cowen and Company.

There's been some additional pricing capability because of the needs and particularly focus on the higher spec rigs, super-spec type applications. So we are starting to see that for contracts that we've been bidding and that we've been awarded for the most part.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's great, but fair to say there sort of upward pricing momentum across the spectrum of your offering?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. That's why we expect the time we did talking about the performance that we've seen. I think, again, customers are willing to pay for performance. Obviously, we've been in a one heck of a downturn, so to be able to be in a position to hopefully
componenttext: I think so. That's why we expect the time we did talking about the performance that we've seen. I think, again, customers are willing to pay for performance. Obviously, we've been in a one heck of a downturn, so to be able to be in a position to hopefully be able to get a return on the investments that we're making with these upgrades. So yes, that would be our expectation. But again, we expect it to be pretty slow.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shirt. Okay, maybe just one more on that CapEx that you're talking about for 2017. I think Juan Pablo, you said about 30% of that is directed towards maintenance leaving $140 million for other stuff. I'm assuming most of that's upgrade, that would imply p
componenttext: Shirt. Okay, maybe just one more on that CapEx that you're talking about for 2017. I think Juan Pablo, you said about 30% of that is directed towards maintenance leaving $140 million for other stuff. I'm assuming most of that's upgrade, that would imply perhaps you're upgrading more than 40 rigs that you talked about to get from where you are now to the 120 at the end of next quarter. So just kind of curious if that's right or maybe what some of those other buckets might be?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that is fair. Of course, we've already spent some money in fiscal 2017 getting to the AED that we mentioned. But is fair to assume that we will continue to upgrade the fleet and some rigs require or we are planning for greater investments tha
componenttext: Yes, I think that is fair. Of course, we've already spent some money in fiscal 2017 getting to the AED that we mentioned. But is fair to assume that we will continue to upgrade the fleet and some rigs require or we are planning for greater investments than the $1 million might suggest. As John said, investments might require $2 million or more million dollars to rig. And so it's a combination of making sure that we are ahead of the game. But we have great flexibility. We don't have to upgrade all 270 rigs that are capable of becoming super-specs, but we are very well prepared to be ahead of the market and trying to make sure that the timing does not represent a bottleneck for us as we continue through -- as you say, as we hopefully continue through this recovery.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, if I could, one more modeling. Is there OpEx number we should be thinking about for standby rigs? Usually just sort of think about pure margin there, but is there any OpEx associated with that, that would maybe be showing up in the cost number?
componenttext: Okay, if I could, one more modeling. Is there OpEx number we should be thinking about for standby rigs? Usually just sort of think about pure margin there, but is there any OpEx associated with that, that would maybe be showing up in the cost number?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, very low. Very, very low. We are talking about probably 11 -- 10% level -- 5% of what a typical operating rig would be running at. We mentioned we only have a handful of rigs on standby at this point that are generating revenue days and we're protect
componenttext: Yes, very low. Very, very low. We are talking about probably 11 -- 10% level -- 5% of what a typical operating rig would be running at. We mentioned we only have a handful of rigs on standby at this point that are generating revenue days and we're protecting the margin on those. But it's very, very low.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Robert Mackenzie with Iberia Capital.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Robert Mackenzie with Iberia Capital.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016

componenttext: I wanted to shift gears, I guess, maybe you said it but maybe I didn't catch it. Offshore. I know you talked a lot about offshore. You're guiding revenue days to be unchanged in the first fiscal quarter, but rig margin to expand quite substantially. Can you give us some color as to why that shift should occur?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Juan Pablo. It's been interesting to watch that segment, about a handful of rigs, the 7 that were active and on customer platforms were receiving day rates on standby type conditions. So in essence, they were inactive, but generating revenue
componenttext: Sure. This is Juan Pablo. It's been interesting to watch that segment, about a handful of rigs, the 7 that were active and on customer platforms were receiving day rates on standby type conditions. So in essence, they were inactive, but generating revenue. We've seen a couple of those rigs go back to work at operating day rates, which create of course margins that are higher than would be generated udner standby type conditions. And that's creating a favorable impact that is -- and that's why we're increasing -- excuse me, that's why we are expecting an increase in the margins there.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of what you call revenue days and if you're receiving a standby rate even not working, you're considering that the revenue day?
componenttext: So in terms of what you call revenue days and if you're receiving a standby rate even not working, you're considering that the revenue day?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. And then coming back to some of Michael's questions early on about the term of new contracts. It sounds like you said that you're getting some term contracts of over a year now, but I didn't hear your answer on how you're protecting yourself and pre
componenttext: Good. And then coming back to some of Michael's questions early on about the term of new contracts. It sounds like you said that you're getting some term contracts of over a year now, but I didn't hear your answer on how you're protecting yourself and preparing for either cost inflation or rates rising in the future. How do you think about structuring term contracts over a year now to not give away too much upside?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robert, this is John. We only entered into 4 and there were some total often. Okay, so you're going -- so there's some part particular tide to why we entered into those. What we've been saying all along is that don't expect us to enter into a lot of term
componenttext: Robert, this is John. We only entered into 4 and there were some total often. Okay, so you're going -- so there's some part particular tide to why we entered into those. What we've been saying all along is that don't expect us to enter into a lot of term contracts in this kind of a pricing environment. The protection we have, if expenses go up, then we have protection contract to cover that. So our margin is held firm. But the majority of the contracts that we'll be entering into or have entered into are going to be spot market based pricing. And so our protection is, in an improving environment, is typically a will to other agreement and we would increase pricing in the next logical well, assuming we see that kind of pricing increase. Does that answer your question?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it very much does. And I guess the question that also follows is that -- are those term contracts 1 year or more, is there any kind of differentiation between kind of the standard Flex 3 or 5 versus the super-spec rig or is it across-the-board?
componenttext: Yes, it very much does. And I guess the question that also follows is that -- are those term contracts 1 year or more, is there any kind of differentiation between kind of the standard Flex 3 or 5 versus the super-spec rig or is it across-the-board?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some of those would've been standard rigs and some rigs would have had some upgrades and may have already head existing upgrades. I don't know for sure whether -- I know we didn't have an investment in all 10 of those, but some would be standard, some wou
componenttext: Some of those would've been standard rigs and some rigs would have had some upgrades and may have already head existing upgrades. I don't know for sure whether -- I know we didn't have an investment in all 10 of those, but some would be standard, some would be super-spec and some we would have made the upgrade.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Rob, were you also asking about the pricing on those?
componenttext: And Rob, were you also asking about the pricing on those?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you've already answered the question. It's actually more about the mix. And then on super-spec just the whole capacity. I mean, given your capacity and what we've heard from others, it sounds like the established players have more than enough capa
componenttext: I think you've already answered the question. It's actually more about the mix. And then on super-spec just the whole capacity. I mean, given your capacity and what we've heard from others, it sounds like the established players have more than enough capacity to meet client demand in a fairly modest growth scenario?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My impression is it's pretty tight. I mean based on what I've seen from the other contractors and again, Juan Pablo made a point, we've talked about what we could do. But we're the only one that has a real upside in how we can respond without having to bu
componenttext: My impression is it's pretty tight. I mean based on what I've seen from the other contractors and again, Juan Pablo made a point, we've talked about what we could do. But we're the only one that has a real upside in how we can respond without having to build a new rig or without having to have some pretty major investments. Our other peers have a fairly limited number of AC drive, 1,500 horsepower rigs to source. And so my feeling is it's a pretty tight market. So I guess, that's my perception.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So given that then, coming back to the pricing question, and do you expect to see the premium for these types of rigs continue to or expand our continue to expand over non-super-spec rigs?
componenttext: So given that then, coming back to the pricing question, and do you expect to see the premium for these types of rigs continue to or expand our continue to expand over non-super-spec rigs?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's logical. I mean, the reality of the rigs are working really hard, they're really good dwells for customers that the rate on the rig doesn't really move the cost needle on the curb. So I think there's an opportunity to increase pricing
componenttext: Well, I think that's logical. I mean, the reality of the rigs are working really hard, they're really good dwells for customers that the rate on the rig doesn't really move the cost needle on the curb. So I think there's an opportunity to increase pricing. Again, we're starting at a very low level. But anything, I think at this stage of the game, we would all be pleased to just get some additional $1,000, $2000 a day here and there. So I think there's opportunities. I don't think there's any doubt that the super spec grade should, the premium over rigs that don't have those additional investments or don't have the capability or don't perform well. I think that's the other point to make is just because you have the rig doesn't mean that you're going to necessarily be able to deliver the performance and the value that the customer requires.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We probably have time for one more question.
componenttext: We probably have time for one more question.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our final question from Sean Meakim from JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll take our final question from Sean Meakim from JPMorgan.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to continue on that line of questioning. We characterizing the market, the supply for super-spec rig is being limited in the press release. And the market's fairly tight. We've heard from other peers this quarter, just offhand and I think is well ove
componenttext: Just to continue on that line of questioning. We characterizing the market, the supply for super-spec rig is being limited in the press release. And the market's fairly tight. We've heard from other peers this quarter, just offhand and I think is well over 100 rigs that are upgradable as a collective group, so you have that with yours. Given the modest capital cost and how quickly you can get these upgrades between jobs, doesn't that suggest that couple of hundred more rigs back to work in this class in order to see pricing these continue or seems like they do think you agree with that?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll make certain I understood your question. So you're saying that we've made the comment that there seem to be a tighter supply and you're suggesting that there's over 100 and that would be available outside...
componenttext: We'll make certain I understood your question. So you're saying that we've made the comment that there seem to be a tighter supply and you're suggesting that there's over 100 and that would be available outside...

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Among your peers.
componenttext: Among your peers.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Among our peers. And I think if you start to think about it in terms of rather than looking at it as an entire fleet of rigs and focus on the rigs that are drilling horizontal and directional wells that do have the higher capability needs, not just becaus
componenttext: Among our peers. And I think if you start to think about it in terms of rather than looking at it as an entire fleet of rigs and focus on the rigs that are drilling horizontal and directional wells that do have the higher capability needs, not just because somebody wants to but because they need it. That's when you start getting into more of our scarcity where I think you have the potential for at least some pricing power. I'm not talking about $25,000 a day. I'm talking about getting additional, getting higher rates and improving our margins. I'm not making any sort of prediction on how high they might go. But I think that does begin to tighten the market. I think the other element is that these rigs, you can't just continue to drill the kind of wells that the industry's drilling and not get paid for it as a subcontractor. The rigs are working harder, you get 7,500-psi pumps, engines are working harder, pumps are working harder, we're using more consumables, costs are going to have to -- I think you begin to put cost pressure in the equation. So anything in general, we're going to see improved pricing. I think there's an opportunity to differentiate substantially over our peers. I think as we have in the past were going to be able to command a premium.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I'm trying to get is my last count earlier this year, there's perhaps 300 super-spec rigs around the number and another 400 across the rest of the group that could be upgraded to that under the conditions discussed earlier, which are pretty simple. S
componenttext: What I'm trying to get is my last count earlier this year, there's perhaps 300 super-spec rigs around the number and another 400 across the rest of the group that could be upgraded to that under the conditions discussed earlier, which are pretty simple. So is if that's the case, on the supply available rigs to do that kind of work, but it's pretty considerable relative to where the horizontal rig count is today and you know that there's that's not certainly looking for that optimal work. So that's what I was rent to get, the still a good out there option entity you guys have.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And that's part of the problem is it's not quite -- the "super-spec" rig isn't as transparent as I'm sure everybody would like and I think everybody, to a degree, working from different definition. We've seen the range published of 150 to 250 rigs
componenttext: Right. And that's part of the problem is it's not quite -- the "super-spec" rig isn't as transparent as I'm sure everybody would like and I think everybody, to a degree, working from different definition. We've seen the range published of 150 to 250 rigs that are "super-spec". There's a little over 700, 1500-horsepower rig, AC rigs, but we don't believe all to those have the capability to be upgraded to super-spec capacity. They don't have the mass structure, they don't have the higher hook load capacity. I think there's a fewer number of rigs that people are anticipating that are capable of doing the kind of work that's being done. But again that's our perspective. It's hard to nail it down because you don't have all the facts.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. That's a very fair point. That's an important caveat. So last piece would be, with these upgrades that you're doing are you willing to fund them on spec or is the idea that you need to get some level of increase in rate to justify that capital
componenttext: Understood. That's a very fair point. That's an important caveat. So last piece would be, with these upgrades that you're doing are you willing to fund them on spec or is the idea that you need to get some level of increase in rate to justify that capital commitment?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Up to this point, it's been the price of admission to work the rig in the areas where it's been needed. And again, not all rigs needed, I think, what is it, David, 80% of our working fleet is super-spec, is that...
componenttext: Up to this point, it's been the price of admission to work the rig in the areas where it's been needed. And again, not all rigs needed, I think, what is it, David, 80% of our working fleet is super-spec, is that...

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we still have customers that don't need the higher spec. But our intent is to get paid through that. I think in general we're probably getting paybacks in 1 to 2 years, it's kind of the way we're looking at it. But I think in a lot of cases, that's goi
componenttext: So we still have customers that don't need the higher spec. But our intent is to get paid through that. I think in general we're probably getting paybacks in 1 to 2 years, it's kind of the way we're looking at it. But I think in a lot of cases, that's going to be the price of admission to compete on these wells.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this time, I'll turn the call back over to our speakers for closing comments.
componenttext: At this time, I'll turn the call back over to our speakers for closing comments.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, thank you. I want to adjust quickly thank each of you again for joining us on the call today. And before we sign off here, just couple of quick final thoughts. Just to reiterate, we believe our AC FlexRig fleet is positioned to take market share in
componenttext: Tony, thank you. I want to adjust quickly thank each of you again for joining us on the call today. And before we sign off here, just couple of quick final thoughts. Just to reiterate, we believe our AC FlexRig fleet is positioned to take market share in the strong or even a moderate U.S. land market recovery. We think we are uniquely leverage to provide E&P companies the rig of choice to drill the more challenging horizontal wells, the design of our FlexRig fleet allows for a broad range of rig upgrades providing family of solutions for our customers. So we thank you again for your time and have a good day.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This does conclude today's conference. You may disconnect at any time and have a great day.
componenttext: Thank you. This does conclude today's conference. You may disconnect at any time and have a great day.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year-end Earnings Conference Call for Helmerich & Payne. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this call may be recorded. I will be standing by if you should need any assistance.And it'
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year-end Earnings Conference Call for Helmerich & Payne. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this call may be recorded. I will be standing by if you should need any assistance.
And it's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. David Hardie, Manager of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's conference call and webcast, corresponding to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.With us today are John Lindsay, President and CEO; and Juan Pablo Tardio, Vice President and CFO. John and Jua
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's conference call and webcast, corresponding to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.
With us today are John Lindsay, President and CEO; and Juan Pablo Tardio, Vice President and CFO. John and Juan Pablo will be sharing some comments with us, after which, we will open the call for questions.
As usual, and as defined by the US Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, all forward-looking statements made during this call are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties as discussed in the company's annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. The company's actual results may differ materially from those indicated or implied by such forward-looking statements.
We will also be making reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures such as segment operating income and operating statistics. You may find the GAAP reconciliation comments and calculations on the last page of today's press release.
I'll now turn the call over to John Lindsay.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Thank you again for joining us on the call.We're pleased to deliver better-than-expected quarterly operational results in the midst of this improving U.S. land market. Our goal is to safely provide performanc
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Thank you again for joining us on the call.
We're pleased to deliver better-than-expected quarterly operational results in the midst of this improving U.S. land market. Our goal is to safely provide performance-driven drilling services, and as we think about the future, I think it's helpful to step back and properly frame where the company is today.
There are 3 main areas I'd like to focus on this morning: first, the success we've had in reactivating idle FlexRigs; second, the leadership position we have in the Permian; and third, some reasons why H&P is in a good position to continue to build its market share.
Let's start with the reactivation of over 32 FlexRigs since the trough of activity in May. Of those rigs, 28 are in the spot market and 4 on term contract, 15 were in the Permian, 5 in the Oklahoma Woodford, 3 each in the Bakken and Haynesville and 2 each in the Eagle Ford, Powder River Basin and Niobrara.
From a FlexRig model perspective, 22 were FlexRig3s and 10 were FlexRig5s. There's a perception by some that the Flex3 isn't as competitive as other models of rigs in the market. Of course, our customers know differently. The Flex 3 continues to be the workhorse of the fleet and delivers great value for customers. Of the 32 rigs, 75% were pad capable and had 7,500-psi mud pumps. These rigs meet the general criteria of what some industry followers have identified as super-spec rigs, and we've also added 14 new customers since May, and momentum has been building as a result of the performance our people are delivering. Our goal is to respond quickly to customer requests, provide problem-free start-ups and deliver very safe, efficient and reliable performance.
We're pleased to have delivered great results, particularly on the very first well drilled by each of the reactivated FlexRigs. Let me give you a few examples of this performance. The rig mobilizations out of our facilities have averaged less than 4 days from the rig down in our facility to moving the rig to the first location, rigging up and being ready to drill. Subsequent moves after the first well have averaged less than 2 days. As far as drilling times by comparing customer AFEs and offset well data, we been able to determine that most of the FlexRigs drill the very first well under the AFE, some have been 20% to 30% under AFE and there's -- have been many that have been record wells. In addition to the efficient rig moves and delivering world-class drilling performance, the 32 rigs have actually averaged lower than 1% downtime, which is aligned with the rest of our working fleet.
Our people and the rigs are to be commended for the high levels of service attitude, performance and value created for our customers and shareholders. Our workforce staffing effort has also been very successful in rehiring previous employees for our reactivated rigs. We've had close to a 90% success rate as we've reached out to previous field employees, resulting in hundreds of quality employees returning to H&P. In fact, all of our rig staffing needs have been provided by rehires up to this point. Another benefit this creates is the opportunity to promote our people. As you can imagine, this is a big boost to the organization's morale.
Another success related to our rig activations is our 24/7 center of excellence for safety, learning and performance. The center of excellence works hand-in-hand providing support services to our field operations so they can deliver operational excellence to our customers. They've developed systems that utilize predictive analytics, which help us reduce nonproductive time, enhance reliability and optimize operational performance. All of these systems working in unison shorten the learning curve and allows sharing of best practices between rigs, driving performance improvements in a shorter time frame and across the fleet. I would be remiss if I didn't also mention the crews and their supervisors that have managed our idle fleet of FlexRigs, and they've turned the process around to reactivating rigs. They have shown great teamwork and have worked very hard to preserve our idle FlexRig equipment stored in our facilities and also to utilize the consumables throughout the fleet. Thanks to each of you for this great effort.
Shifting to the Permian. With all the headlines, it isn't a surprise that we've activated more FlexRigs there than in any other basin. It is equally important to stress the capabilities we have in our Permian operations. We invested heavily on our infrastructure in the Permian back in 2012 through 2014, and it is our largest facility today, and at the peak, we were working just shy of 90 rigs in West Texas and had expectations to work as many as 125 rigs prior to the downturn. Today, we have 49 rigs contracted coming off a low of 37 rigs. We have 71 idle FlexRigs in the area, and 51 of those are 1,500-horsepower, and we expect to continue to have opportunities to grow our active fleet in the Permian.
In addition to having our FlexRig offering, we also have additional services in our Permian operation where we provide rig move trucks and casing running capability for our rigs. We've operated our own rig move trucking fleets since 1994, and today, we are the only major drilling contractor that owns and operates a rig move trucking fleet. Our ability to control the rig move process offers substantial advantages and efficiencies, safety and reliability to our operations and customers. Historically, we have ranged between 30% to 40% of all rig moves in theU.S. with our trucking fleet, and that's similar to our Permian activity today.
For over 10 years, we've offered casing running services in our U.S. land fleet. Like trucking, using our casing running personnel and tools provide competitive advantages and safety and productivity for our people and customers. Of the 14 new customers since May, 8 are working rigs in the Permian. We're seeing that the Permian is leading the recovery in having this infrastructure in place. Certainly, it will be in advantage going forward.
The third area I want to focus on is H&Ps market position to continue efforts to grow our market share in U.S. land. The market today recognizes the advantages of 1,500-horsepower AC drive rigs because those rigs are best designed for the complexity and longer laterals for horizontal shale wells and customer demand for high levels of performance and reliability. From a rig requirement perspective, extended laterals require more hydraulic horsepower, drill strength torque and greater capability from technology solutions that 1,500-horsepower AC rigs provide and therefore, they are the rig of choice.
We estimate that H&P has approximately 55% of the available 1,500-horsepower AC rig in U.S. land today. So we're positioned with more capacity than any of our competitors in the market. We currently have 104 1,500-horsepower AC drive FlexRigs under contract and 220 idle and available to go to work in the U.S. We have 19% share of the U.S. land horizontal directional drilling market, with our closest competitor at 11%. We have slightly grown our market share from 18% since the peak of activity in 2014. We are very hopeful that the market provides an opportunity to utilize our spare capacity and build on the lead we have.
Another example of H&P's industry-leading position is our current fleet of AC drive FlexRigs that have 7,500-psi circulating systems and multi-well pad drilling capability. As mentioned earlier, these rigs meet the general criteria of what some industry followers have identified as super-spec rigs, which is a subset of AC drive rigs with 1,500-horsepower drawworks ratings. We have approximately 80 of these rigs in our U.S. land fleet, and if demand remains high, we could upgrade additional FlexRigs and have approximately 120 of these rigs by the end of our 2017 second fiscal quarter.
The industry's capacity to provide additional super-spec rigs appears to be limited today, which positions H&P very well for future expansion in the space. Should there be a significant market demand for super-spec rigs going forward, H&P has the capability of providing approximately 270 super-spec FlexRigs to the market without requiring new-build rigs, solely through upgrades were needed to our current FlexRig3 and FlexRig5 fleet. Unlike many of our competitors, we don't need to build new rigs today. Our design allows H&P to invest in our existing fleet to enhance capabilities that will benefit our customers in this more challenging and complex environment. We can do this in a scalable and cost-effective way by leveraging our uniform base of existing FlexRig designs.
Our spare capacity, combined with our strong balance sheet, gives us great flexibility to invest in the fleet, providing a family of solutions to meet customer needs and provide value to shareholders.
So before turning the call to Juan Pablo, it is clear the upcoming OPEC meeting is weighing on the oil markets, and yet, even though oil prices have pulled back over the past several weeks, it's still encouraging to see signs of optimism in the market as we're continuing to reactivate idle rigs out of our facilities safely, efficiently and cost-effectively.
And now I'll turn the call over to Juan Pablo.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John.As reported this morning, the company had a net loss of approximately $73 million during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, resulting in an annual net loss of approximately $57 million during fiscal 2016. Nevertheless, operational result
componenttext:
Thank you, John.
As reported this morning, the company had a net loss of approximately $73 million during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, resulting in an annual net loss of approximately $57 million during fiscal 2016. Nevertheless, operational results were better than expected during the fourth quarter and market improvement signs are encouraging. We are now expecting our second consecutive quarter-to-quarter improvement in overall activity during the first quarter of fiscal 2017.
Following our -- some details on each of our 3 drilling segments. Our U.S. land drilling segment reported an operating loss of approximately $70 million during the fourth fiscal quarter. Nevertheless, the number of revenue days increased by approximately 6% compared to the prior quarter, resulting in an average of close to 86 rigs generating revenue days during the fourth fiscal quarter. On average, approximately 67 of these rigs were under term contract and approximately 19 rigs worked in the spot market.
Excluding the impact of early termination revenues, the average rig revenue per day declined by approximately 1% to $24,404 in the fourth fiscal quarter as a proportion of rigs working in the spot market increased significantly quarter-to-quarter. The average rig expense per day decreased by less than 1% to $13,326, excluding the lawsuit settlement then adjustments to self-insurance reserves. The corresponding rig margin per day during the fourth fiscal quarter was $11,078.
The segment generated approximately $30 million in revenues, corresponding to early termination of long-term contracts during the fourth fiscal quarter. No early termination notices have been received or announced since our last call in July. But given prior notifications, we expect to generate approximately $9 million during the first fiscal quarter and a total of over $30 million during several quarters thereafter in early termination revenues.
Since the peak in late 2014, we have received early termination notifications for a total of 88 rigs under long-term contracts in the segment. Total early termination revenues related to these 88 contracts are estimated at approximately $466 million. As of today, our 348 available rigs in the U.S. land segment include approximately 105 rigs generating revenue and 243 idle rigs. Included in the 105 rigs generating revenue are 72 rigs under term contracts, 69 of which are generating revenue days. In addition, 33 rigs are currently active in the spot market, for a total of 102 rigs generating revenue days in the segment as compared to 86 rigs during our last earnings call in late July. Approximately 4% of these 102 rigs are now idle and on standby type day rates, which protect daily cash margins under long-term contracts. Separately, the 3 rigs that are not generating revenue days include new-build rigs with deliveries that have been delayed in exchange for compensation from customers.
Looking ahead to the first quarter of fiscal 2017, we expect a quarter-to-quarter increase in activity of roughly 20% in terms of revenue days. Excluding the impact of revenues corresponding to early terminated long-term contracts, we expect our average rig revenue per day to decline to approximately $23,500, primarily as a result of a higher proportion of rigs working in the spot market. Although we have experienced spot pricing stabilization and are now beginning to see some spot pricing improvement, the average pricing today for the 33 rigs in the spot market is still over 35% lower as compared with our spot pricing at the peak in late 2014.
The average rig expense per day level is expected to increase to roughly $14,200. This expected increase is primarily attributable to a significantly lower proportion of rigs generating revenue days while on standby, down from almost 13% of revenue days in the prior quarter to an expected level of under 5% in the first fiscal quarter. Although we expect this average expense level to eventually come down to more normalized levels during a recovery, the transitional or rig start-up expenses along with the carrying cost of over 200 idle and available AC drive FlexRigs are temporarily and unfavorably impacting the average.
If we isolate rigs that are currently active, their average expense level is at approximately $13,000 per rig per day, which is similar to overall levels experienced in more stable time periods like 2013 and 2014. Absent any additional early terminations and excluding the aforementioned rigs for which we have received early termination notifications, the segment currently has term contract commitments in place for an average of approximately 69 rigs during the first fiscal quarter, 68 rigs during the remaining 3 quarters of fiscal 2017, 39 rigs during fiscal 2018 and 17 rigs during fiscal 2019. These commitments include about 10 rigs that have relatively recently been placed under term contracts, with pricing at slightly higher than current spot market levels. Thus, as we include this newly contracted rigs, the average daily margin for rigs that are currently under term contracts is now expected to decline, moving from the prior $15,000 to $16,000 range to a new range between $14,000 and $15,000 per day during the next few quarters.
Let me now transition to our offshore operations. Segment operating income slightly increased to approximately $3 million, total revenue days slightly increased and the average rig margin per day increased by about 14% during the fourth fiscal quarter to $9,070 per day excluding employee severance expenses in the prior quarter and self-insurance reserve adjustments during the quarter. Most of the rigs that generated revenue during the fourth fiscal quarter were rigs that remained idle on customer-owned platforms and were generating standby type day rates.
As we look at the first quarter of fiscal 2017, we expect quarterly revenue days to remain flat at 7 of our 9 offshore platform rigs continue to generate revenue days during the quarter. The average rig margin per day is expected to increase to approximately $11,250 per day during the first fiscal quarter. The expected increase is primarily attributable to 2 of 5 rigs that were previously on standby type day rates returning to work at operating day rates.
Management contracts on platform rigs continue to contribute to our offshore segment operating income. Their contribution during the fourth fiscal quarter, however, was lower than expected at under $2 million. Nevertheless, management contracts are expected to once again generate around $3 million in operating income during each of the next few quarters.
Moving on to our international land operations. This segment reported operating losses of approximately $200,000 during the fourth fiscal quarter. Excluding the impact of employee severance expenses during the prior quarter, the average rig margin per day increased sequentially by approximately 12% to $10,619 per day. The increase was primarily attributable to favorable retroactive pricing adjustments and to the absence of unexpected temporary rate reduction that was mentioned during our late July call. Quarterly revenue days increased sequentially by approximately 8% to 1,372 days as 2 rigs commenced operations during the quarter. As of today, our international land segment has 14 rigs generating revenue days, including 11 in Argentina, 2 in Colombia and 1 in Bahrain. 12 of these rigs are under long-term contracts.
We expect approximately $5 million in compensation related to early terminations for 2 rigs in this segment during the first quarter of fiscal 2017. As a result, we expect international land quarterly revenue days to decrease by approximately 5% during that quarter as compared to the fourth fiscal quarter. Excluding the impact of early termination revenues, the average rig margin per day is expected to decrease to approximately $8,000 per day as a result of several factors including the expected absence of the early terminated rigs that were generating higher than average rig margins and more of the rigs under term contracts now at standby type day rates.
When we combine all 3 of our drilling segments and exclude rigs with long-term contracts that have been early terminated, we currently have an average of approximately 82 rigs under term contracts expected to be active in fiscal 2017, 51 in fiscal 2018 and 27 in fiscal 2019.
Let me now comment on corporate level details. Our balance sheet and liquidity remain very strong. Our backlog also remains strong at $1.8 billion as of September 30. Fiscal 2017 CapEx is estimated to be around $200 million, about 30% of which is expected to be related to maintenance CapEx and tubulars and the remainder mostly to upgrades of our existing fleet. We continue to be in great position to sustain regular dividend levels and with great flexibility to take advantage of future opportunities. After this extremely challenging time for everyone in the business, we are now the only investment-grade rated company in our sector and one on a very short list within the entire oil field services universe.
Total depreciation for fiscal 2017 is expected to decline to approximately $525 million and general and administrative expenses to approximately $140 million. The reduction in the depreciation expense estimate is primarily attributable to relatively low levels of capital expenditures during fiscal 2016 and 2017. The effective income tax rate on the loss for fiscal 2016 was approximately 27%, significantly different than expected, given that instead of a slight gain for the fiscal year, we experienced a significant loss as a result of the expected -- of the unexpected select items that impacted the fourth fiscal quarter. The effective income tax rate for fiscal 2017 is, at this point, expected to be around 36%.
As of September 30, other current assets in our condensed balance sheet include a prepaid tax balance of $26 million and a tax receivable balance of $38 million. Also included in current assets are approximately $50 million related to insurance receivables, which are more than offset by approximately $72 million included in current liabilities in our condensed balance sheet related to the mentioned lawsuit settlement. We have a portfolio of equity securities consisting of Atwood Oceanics, Inc. and Schlumberger Limited that is reported under Investments in our balance sheet. And we have been monetizing these holdings over the years and recording very significant gains from the corresponding sales. Nevertheless, our $4 million share position in Atwood was determined to be an other than temporary loss during the fourth quarter as a result of the length of time that its share price had been under our corresponding cost. As a result, we recognized a $26 million impairment charge, equivalent to an after-tax loss of approximately $0.15 per share. This compares to an after-tax gain of approximately $0.86 per share recorded in 2013 when we monetized 4 million shares of our Atwood holdings and reduced that position in half.
As we have in the past, we will probably hold our existing portfolio positions through this downturn and once again, start to monetize them during more attractive times through the cycles. Our noncurrent deferred income tax liability as of September 30, 2016, was slightly over $1.3 billion, which is slightly higher than the prior year-end level. We expect this lability level to remain in the range of $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion during the next couple of years.
With that, let me turn the call back to John.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Juan Pablo.Prior to opening the call for questions, I want to reiterate a few points. We strongly believe H&P is the best fleet, especially for the more technically challenging horizontal shale wells. And equally, if not more important, we al
componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo.
Prior to opening the call for questions, I want to reiterate a few points. We strongly believe H&P is the best fleet, especially for the more technically challenging horizontal shale wells. And equally, if not more important, we also have the people, the systems and the operational support structures to drive the highest levels of performance and reliability for our customers. We've accumulated more than 1,800 rig years of AC drive operational experience. Our expertise designing, building and now upgrading the fleet provides great optionality for the customer and has resulted in H&P having the largest and most capable fleet of AC drive rigs in the industry.
We remain committed to further expand our competitive advantages through technology and the scale of our operations in order to continue to add value to our customers and shareholders.
And Tony, we will now open the call for questions.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Michael LaMotte with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Michael LaMotte with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, what is the -- roughly the cost of upgrading a 1,500 to a super-spec? Wait. And what are you looking at in terms of components to accomplish that?
componenttext: John, what is the -- roughly the cost of upgrading a 1,500 to a super-spec? Wait. And what are you looking at in terms of components to accomplish that?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we were to use a base Flex3 that didn't already have a pad system, then it would be to add 7,500 in the pad system would be approximately $2 million.
componenttext: If we were to use a base Flex3 that didn't already have a pad system, then it would be to add 7,500 in the pad system would be approximately $2 million.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we already had the -- which there are Flex3s that are idle, that have the pad application, the skid system that are idle. So there's several that we will just upgrade with just the 7,500. And then there's also some, in some cases, we're upgrading the s
componenttext: If we already had the -- which there are Flex3s that are idle, that have the pad application, the skid system that are idle. So there's several that we will just upgrade with just the 7,500. And then there's also some, in some cases, we're upgrading the setback capacity. That's a relatively small investment. I want to say it's around $200,000-or-so. There's some folks that include -- in a super-spec, the third pump and the fourth engine, the way we've approached it, Michael, is it's really on a needs basis. If the customer has a true need for the third pump or the fourth engine, if the hydraulics requirements are there, then that's what we're doing. But it really depends on basin and it's really dependent customer to customer, whether you need 2 or whether you need 3. And that's a relatively small incremental investment. Obviously, we already own the pumps and the engines. It's just really the installation cost, the rigs are set up and designed to accept the additional equipment.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then about how much time, if you're doing the full $2 million, how much time do you need to get all that work done?
componenttext: Okay. And then about how much time, if you're doing the full $2 million, how much time do you need to get all that work done?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it -- a lot of it, as you can imagine, is kind of like asking us the question how, long does it take to build a FlexRig because a lot of the work is being done offline. If you're doing the work on a rig during a rig move, which happens occasionally,
componenttext: Well, it -- a lot of it, as you can imagine, is kind of like asking us the question how, long does it take to build a FlexRig because a lot of the work is being done offline. If you're doing the work on a rig during a rig move, which happens occasionally, you're talking about a couple of extra days. If it's being done on a rig that is -- that has been idle, again, it doesn't take very long. A lot of the manufacturing, the fabrication is being done offline in our facilities similar to the -- or in the facilities that we've used to build rigs in the past. So as you can imagine, it's being done offline. The fleet profile is uniform, so it's kind of a lean manufacturing effort, if you will. So it's kind of hard to say how long it takes for a rig that's idle, it really doesn't make any difference because it's being done offline. During a rig move, I want to say it's 2 to 4 days. I don't remember exact, but I think that's right.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So -- I -- the important thing is it's not a month. It really is pretty quick. And then last one for me. On those super-specs, just in terms of the inquiries that you're getting as you sort of look forward into the demand, is it a third of the incre
componenttext: Okay. So -- I -- the important thing is it's not a month. It really is pretty quick. And then last one for me. On those super-specs, just in terms of the inquiries that you're getting as you sort of look forward into the demand, is it a third of the incremental inquiry? Half? What's roughly the mix in terms of what customers are coming to you for today?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That is a great question. I wish I would have thought about that and had the answer for you. I'd think about looking at a lot of our market lines. Surprisingly enough, we still have -- I say surprising because there's so much focus on super-spec. We
componenttext: Yes. That is a great question. I wish I would have thought about that and had the answer for you. I'd think about looking at a lot of our market lines. Surprisingly enough, we still have -- I say surprising because there's so much focus on super-spec. We still have customers that are still -- their requirement, their need base is a FlexRig3, some are single well, some are pad with 2 pumps and 5,000-psi. If I were to guess, I'd say it's anywhere from half to 75% is kind of what I would estimate today. We made a note in our comments that for the rigs, the 32 rigs that we reactivated, 75% of those were super-spec and worked with a pad and 7,500-psi. And again, to be clear, some of those 7,500 had 2 pumps and some had 3. And again, it's based upon what the customers' needs are.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll move to Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next, we'll move to Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, I know there's a lot of different semantics flying around the marketplace in terms of super-spec and obviously, one of your larger competitors over the last couple of weeks had an Analyst Day and talked about some additional technology that they
componenttext: So John, I know there's a lot of different semantics flying around the marketplace in terms of super-spec and obviously, one of your larger competitors over the last couple of weeks had an Analyst Day and talked about some additional technology that they were adding to the mix. By focusing on the super-spec, as you referenced it, and focusing on the term pad-optimal, does that pad-optimal include walking systems? Or is that just your current skid system?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The pad-optimal, our pad capability, whatever you call it, is still as we've described, our skid systems for Flex3s and Flex5s. Of course, Flex4s were designed with skid capability, pad capability as well. So that is the design, and I mean, you know
componenttext: Yes. The pad-optimal, our pad capability, whatever you call it, is still as we've described, our skid systems for Flex3s and Flex5s. Of course, Flex4s were designed with skid capability, pad capability as well. So that is the design, and I mean, you know because we've talked about it several times. And quite frankly, we've been talking about it for a couple of years now, that when we have the demand from a customer in a meaningful way then that's something that we will do, we can do. We've had -- we have designs for it. And so I'm sure eventually we will do that. But at this stage of the game, what we've described in our fleet are Flex3s and Flex5s in the traditional pad configuration.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess we would -- we take away from your commentary today that again, the vast majority of the customer base is not asking for omnidirectional walking rig capability?
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess we would -- we take away from your commentary today that again, the vast majority of the customer base is not asking for omnidirectional walking rig capability?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do have -- when you say omnidirectional, we do have omnidirectional capability with Flex4s and Flex5s, and -- but the -- typically that isn't the need. And so in the Flex5 -- I'm sorry, the Flex3, if you go back long enough, the initial pads were
componenttext: Well, we do have -- when you say omnidirectional, we do have omnidirectional capability with Flex4s and Flex5s, and -- but the -- typically that isn't the need. And so in the Flex5 -- I'm sorry, the Flex3, if you go back long enough, the initial pads were relatively small, they were 50 to 75 feet. And we have Flex3s today that are actually on 200-foot skid applications that work great. So the omnidirectional portion, the demand we've been able to meet with Flex5s or Flex4s where we've needed it and it really has an impact in our customers' designs as far as using the FlexRig3.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And then maybe -- well, just one more follow-up on the incremental demand. You mentioned additional rigs in a number of different basins. Clearly, the vast majority being in the Permian. With -- what have you been taking up recently in d
componenttext: All right, great. And then maybe -- well, just one more follow-up on the incremental demand. You mentioned additional rigs in a number of different basins. Clearly, the vast majority being in the Permian. With -- what have you been taking up recently in discussion with the E&P customers with respect to increased activity in the Eagle Ford or the Bakken? Obviously, you've mentioned the Haynesville so that kind of captured my attention as well. So outside of the Permian, what are you hearing?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think my sense would be it seems like Eagle Ford compared to the last several months, there have been more inquiries in the Eagle Ford than what we've seen, which is, obviously, great news for us if we can see some material increases because that's our
componenttext: I think my sense would be it seems like Eagle Ford compared to the last several months, there have been more inquiries in the Eagle Ford than what we've seen, which is, obviously, great news for us if we can see some material increases because that's our -- that was our second largest operational area back at the peak. We have great rigs and people and we're set up very well there. As I think about it -- David, I don't know, is there... My sense would be if we continue to have a demand kind of across the board like it has been -- I mean, I look back on this quarter and then the previous quarter and the Permian continue to be just under half and then the other ones are pretty equally distributed.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair, John.
componenttext: I think that's fair, John.

componenttext: Yes. There's just nothing that jumps off the page that says, oh, yes, this is the area. Maybe with the exception of the Eagle Ford, we have had some -- or at least, it seems like some additional discussions.
