componenttext: Next, we'll move to Robin Shoemaker with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, I wanted to ask about the -- on the super-spec rigs, what is the sort of pipe racking capacity that goes with that kind of asset?
componenttext: So John, I wanted to ask about the -- on the super-spec rigs, what is the sort of pipe racking capacity that goes with that kind of asset?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- again, it comes back to definitionally [ph]. We have the standard FlexRig3, which was 22,000 to 23,000 feet. We're upgrading it to a 25,000- to 26,000-foot range. But we're only doing that upgrade -- if you're drilling 18,000-, 20,000-foo
componenttext: Well, we have -- again, it comes back to definitionally [ph]. We have the standard FlexRig3, which was 22,000 to 23,000 feet. We're upgrading it to a 25,000- to 26,000-foot range. But we're only doing that upgrade -- if you're drilling 18,000-, 20,000-foot wells, obviously, by definition, you don't need that additional setback capacity. Flex 5s came out standard with a 25,000- or 26,000-foot setback capacity. I believe I've got that right. So it's really, Robin, in response to what the customer's needs are. We have that capability of -- with a pretty low-cost investment of extending that setback capacity to 25,000 to 26,000 feet.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. I had another question, unrelated. We've been hearing from other drilling contractors and service companies about quite a bit of tendering activity for land rigs in the Middle East, multiple countries. And I wonder if you could comment on that
componenttext: Okay, okay. I had another question, unrelated. We've been hearing from other drilling contractors and service companies about quite a bit of tendering activity for land rigs in the Middle East, multiple countries. And I wonder if you could comment on that and your level of interest in those tenders. Are they the type of rigs? Are they for FlexRigs? Are they the type of rig tenders for which your rigs are suited?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there have been some tenders. I don't remember all the details. We have bid Flex 3s in -- on international projects. I think we've also possibly even bid on some 3,000-horsepower work, which obviously we have 3,000-horsepower SCR rigs as well. So we
componenttext: Yes, there have been some tenders. I don't remember all the details. We have bid Flex 3s in -- on international projects. I think we've also possibly even bid on some 3,000-horsepower work, which obviously we have 3,000-horsepower SCR rigs as well. So we have participated or are at least on the front ends of participating. As far as I know we haven't heard anything back. I think it's still in the early stages at this stage.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, on the -- you mentioned at one point that in the U.S. spot -- average spot rates have come up a little bit from the lowest point. And I wonder if you could -- should we characterize that as a couple of thousand dollars a day? Or is ther
componenttext: Okay. And finally, on the -- you mentioned at one point that in the U.S. spot -- average spot rates have come up a little bit from the lowest point. And I wonder if you could -- should we characterize that as a couple of thousand dollars a day? Or is there some way you can frame that for us?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they have begun to come up. I think it's -- if you go back to our call in July and even some of the conferences that we've been at, we've talked about, there would be a lot of competition coming off the bottom. Kind of looking back in hindsight, you
componenttext: Well, they have begun to come up. I think it's -- if you go back to our call in July and even some of the conferences that we've been at, we've talked about, there would be a lot of competition coming off the bottom. Kind of looking back in hindsight, you can see that May was the trough. And I think our lowest pricing was in August. And so we're starting to see some improvements. I think to generally categorize $1,000 to $2,000 a day is a fine categorization, again depending on the area, depending on the customer, depending on a lot of things. But that's about all the clarity that I think we're willing to talk about at this stage. But I don't think there's any doubt that for high-quality rigs and high-quality performance, our expectation is that there'll start to become some pricing power in the market.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll move to Marc Bianchi with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Next we'll move to Marc Bianchi with Cowen and Company.

componenttext: Maybe following up on that last line of discussion on kind of pricing. Can you talk to where some of these super-spec rigs kind of the -- maybe how much of a margin premium? Or are you seeing a margin premium for those rigs?

componenttext: Marc, there are some today, I mean, we're -- and I say today, recently, I don't know, over the last several weeks. There's been some additional pricing capability because of the needs and particularly focused on the higher spec rigs, super-spec type applications. So we are starting to see that for contracts that we've been bidding and that we've been awarded for the most part.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, that's great, but fair to say there is sort of upward pricing momentum across the spectrum of your offering?
componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's great, but fair to say there is sort of upward pricing momentum across the spectrum of your offering?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. It's why we spent the time we did talking about the performance that we've seen. I think, again, customers are willing to pay for performance. Obviously, we're -- we've been in a -- one heck of a downturn, and so to be able to be in a position
componenttext: I think so. It's why we spent the time we did talking about the performance that we've seen. I think, again, customers are willing to pay for performance. Obviously, we're -- we've been in a -- one heck of a downturn, and so to be able to be in a position to hopefully be able to get a return on the investments that we're making with these upgrades. So yes, that would be our expectation. But again, we expect it to be pretty slow.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, okay. Well, maybe just one more on the CapEx that you're talking about for 2017. I think, Juan Pablo, you said about 30% of that is directed towards maintenance, leaving $140 million for other stuff. I'm assuming most of that's upgrade. That would i
componenttext: Sure, okay. Well, maybe just one more on the CapEx that you're talking about for 2017. I think, Juan Pablo, you said about 30% of that is directed towards maintenance, leaving $140 million for other stuff. I'm assuming most of that's upgrade. That would imply perhaps you're upgrading more than the 40 rigs that you talked about to get from where you are now to the 120 at the end of next quarter. So just kind of curious if that's right or maybe what some of those other buckets might be.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that is fair. Of course, we've already spent some money in fiscal 2017 getting to the 80 that we've mentioned. But it is fair to assume that we will continue to upgrade the fleet, and some rigs require or we are planning for greater investmen
componenttext: Yes. I think that is fair. Of course, we've already spent some money in fiscal 2017 getting to the 80 that we've mentioned. But it is fair to assume that we will continue to upgrade the fleet, and some rigs require or we are planning for greater investment than $1 million might suggest. As John said, investments might require $2 million or more million dollars per rig. And so it's a combination of making sure that we are ahead of the game. But we have great flexibility. We don't have to upgrade all 270 rigs that are capable of becoming super-specs, but we are very well prepared to be ahead of the market and trying to make sure that the timing does not represent a bottleneck for us as we continue through -- or I should say, as we hopefully continue through this recovery.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. If I could, one more modeling. Is there an OpEx number we should be thinking about for standby rigs? We usually just sort of think about the pure margin there, but is there any OpEx associated with that, that would maybe be showing up in the c
componenttext: Okay, okay. If I could, one more modeling. Is there an OpEx number we should be thinking about for standby rigs? We usually just sort of think about the pure margin there, but is there any OpEx associated with that, that would maybe be showing up in the cost number?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, yes. Very low. Very, very low. We are talking about probably less than 10%, less than 5% of what a typical operating rig would be running at. We mentioned we only have a handful of rigs on standby at this point that are generating revenue days,
componenttext: Thank you, yes. Very low. Very, very low. We are talking about probably less than 10%, less than 5% of what a typical operating rig would be running at. We mentioned we only have a handful of rigs on standby at this point that are generating revenue days, and we're protecting the margin on those. But it's very, very low.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a -- I wanted to shift gears, I guess. And maybe you said it, but maybe I didn't catch it. Offshore. I know you talked a lot about land, but offshore, you're guiding revenue days to be unchanged in the first fiscal quarter, but rig margin to expand
componenttext: I had a -- I wanted to shift gears, I guess. And maybe you said it, but maybe I didn't catch it. Offshore. I know you talked a lot about land, but offshore, you're guiding revenue days to be unchanged in the first fiscal quarter, but rig margin to expand quite substantially. Can you give us some color as to why that shift should occur?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Juan Pablo. It's been interesting to watch that segment, about a handful of rigs of the 7 that were active and on customer platforms were receiving day rates on standby type conditions. So in essence, they were inactive, but generating reven
componenttext: Sure. This is Juan Pablo. It's been interesting to watch that segment, about a handful of rigs of the 7 that were active and on customer platforms were receiving day rates on standby type conditions. So in essence, they were inactive, but generating revenue. We've seen a couple of those rigs go back to work at operating day rates, which create, of course, margins that are higher than would be generated under standby type conditions. And that's creating a favorable impact that is -- and that's why we're increasing -- excuse me, that's why we are expecting an increase in the margins there.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of what you call revenue days then, if you're receiving a standby rate even though it's not working, you're considering that a revenue day?
componenttext: So in terms of what you call revenue days then, if you're receiving a standby rate even though it's not working, you're considering that a revenue day?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And then coming back to some of Michael's questions early on about the term of new contracts. It sounds like you've said that you're getting some term contracts of over 1 year now, but I didn't hear your answer on how you're protecting yoursel
componenttext: Okay, good. And then coming back to some of Michael's questions early on about the term of new contracts. It sounds like you've said that you're getting some term contracts of over 1 year now, but I didn't hear your answer on how you're protecting yourself and preparing for either cost inflation or rates rising in the future. How do you think about structuring term contracts of over 1 year now to not give away too much upside?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Robert, this is John. We only entered into 4, and there was some -- oh, so it was a total of 10. Okay, you -- so you're going...
componenttext: Well, Robert, this is John. We only entered into 4, and there was some -- oh, so it was a total of 10. Okay, you -- so you're going...

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back [ph].
componenttext: Going back [ph].

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's some particulars tied to why we entered into those. What we've been saying all along is that don't expect us to enter into a lot of term contracts at -- in this kind of a pricing environment. The protection we have, if price -- if expenses go u
componenttext: So there's some particulars tied to why we entered into those. What we've been saying all along is that don't expect us to enter into a lot of term contracts at -- in this kind of a pricing environment. The protection we have, if price -- if expenses go up, then we have protection in the contract to cover that. So our margin is held firm. But the majority of the contracts that we'll be entering into and have entered into are going to be spot market-based pricing. And so our protection is, in an improving environment, is -- it's typically a well-to-well agreement, and we would increase pricing on the next logical well, assuming we see that kind of pricing increase. Does that answer your question?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it very much does. And I guess the question that also follows is that -- are those term contracts of 1 year or more, is there any kind of differentiation between kind of a standard Flex 3 or 5 versus the super-spec rig? Or is it across-the-board?
componenttext: Yes, it very much does. And I guess the question that also follows is that -- are those term contracts of 1 year or more, is there any kind of differentiation between kind of a standard Flex 3 or 5 versus the super-spec rig? Or is it across-the-board?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some of those would've been standard rigs, and some rigs would have had some upgrades and may have already had existing upgrades. I don't know for sure whether -- I know we didn't have an investment in all 10 of those, but some would be standard, some wou
componenttext: Some of those would've been standard rigs, and some rigs would have had some upgrades and may have already had existing upgrades. I don't know for sure whether -- I know we didn't have an investment in all 10 of those, but some would be standard, some would be super-spec and some of them we would have made the upgrade.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Rob, were you also asking about the pricing on those?
componenttext: And Rob, were you also asking about the pricing on those?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you guys already answered the pricing question.
componenttext: I think you guys already answered the pricing question.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct, correct.
componenttext: Correct, correct.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, yes, I was asking more about the mix. So -- and then on the super-spec, just the whole capacity. I mean, given your capacity and what we've heard from others, does it sound like the established players have more than enough capacity to meet client dem
componenttext: So, yes, I was asking more about the mix. So -- and then on the super-spec, just the whole capacity. I mean, given your capacity and what we've heard from others, does it sound like the established players have more than enough capacity to meet client demand in a fairly modest growth scenario?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My impression is it's pretty tight, I mean, based on what I've seen from the other contractors. And, again, Juan Pablo made the point, we've talked about what we could do. But we're the only one that has a real upside in how we can respond without having
componenttext: My impression is it's pretty tight, I mean, based on what I've seen from the other contractors. And, again, Juan Pablo made the point, we've talked about what we could do. But we're the only one that has a real upside in how we can respond without having to build a new rig or without having to have some pretty major investments. Our other peers have a fairly limited number of AC drive, 1,500-horsepower rigs to source. And so my feeling is it's a pretty tight market. So I guess, that's my perception.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that given that then, coming back to the pricing question, and there's a method here, is -- do you expect to see the premium for these types of rigs continue to -- or expand or continue to expand over non-super-spec rigs?
componenttext: So that given that then, coming back to the pricing question, and there's a method here, is -- do you expect to see the premium for these types of rigs continue to -- or expand or continue to expand over non-super-spec rigs?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- well, I think that's logical. I mean, the reality of it, the rigs are working really hard. They're drilling really good wells for customers that the rate on the rig doesn't really move the cost needle on the curve. So I think there is an opportunity
componenttext: I -- well, I think that's logical. I mean, the reality of it, the rigs are working really hard. They're drilling really good wells for customers that the rate on the rig doesn't really move the cost needle on the curve. So I think there is an opportunity to increase pricing. Again, we're starting at a very low level. But anything, I think at this stage of the game, we would all be pleased to just get some additional $1,000, $2000 a day here and there. So yes, I think there's some opportunities. I don't think there's any doubt that the super-spec rigs should command a premium over rigs that don't have those additional investments or don't have the capability or don't perform well. I think that's the other point to make is just because you have the rig doesn't mean that you're going to necessarily be able to deliver the performance and the value that the customer requires.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We probably have time for one more question.
componenttext: We probably have time for one more question.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our final question from Sean Meakim with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll take our final question from Sean Meakim with JPMorgan.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to continue on that line of questioning. We talked -- you were characterizing the market or the supply for super-spec rigs as being limited in the press release. And you're saying you think the market's fairly tight. We've heard from your other peers
componenttext: Just to continue on that line of questioning. We talked -- you were characterizing the market or the supply for super-spec rigs as being limited in the press release. And you're saying you think the market's fairly tight. We've heard from your other peers this quarter. Just offhand, I think the count is well over 100 rigs that they say are upgradable as a collective group, so you add that with yours. Given the modest capital cost and how quickly these rigs can get these upgrades kind of in between jobs, doesn't that suggest that we need to put a couple hundred more rigs back to work in this class in order to see pricing gains continue? Or seems like, obviously, you don't seem to agree with that?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sean, I want to make certain I understood your question. So you're saying that we've made the comment that there seem to be a tighter supply and you're suggesting that there's over 100 that would be available outside...
componenttext: Sean, I want to make certain I understood your question. So you're saying that we've made the comment that there seem to be a tighter supply and you're suggesting that there's over 100 that would be available outside...

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Among your peers.
componenttext: Among your peers.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Among our peers. Yes. And I think that's where -- if you start to think about it in terms of -- rather than looking at it as an entire fleet of rigs and focus on the rigs that are drilling horizontal and directional wells that do have the higher capabilit
componenttext: Among our peers. Yes. And I think that's where -- if you start to think about it in terms of -- rather than looking at it as an entire fleet of rigs and focus on the rigs that are drilling horizontal and directional wells that do have the higher capability needs, not just because somebody wants it but because they need it, that's when you start getting into more of a scarcity where I think you have the potential for at least some pricing power. And I'm not talking about $25,000 a day. I'm just -- I'm talking about getting additional -- getting higher rates and improving our margins. I'm not making any sort of prediction on how high they might go. But I think that does begin to tighten the market. I think the other element is that these rigs -- you can't just continue to drill the kind of wells that the industry's drilling and not get paid for it as a contractor. The rigs are working harder, you've got 7,500-psi pumps, engines are working harder, pumps are working harder, we're using more consumables. Costs are going to have to -- I think you begin to put cost pressure in the equation. So I think in general, we're going to see improved pricing. I think there is an opportunity to differentiate substantially over our peers. I think that's -- as we have in the past, we're going to be able to command a premium.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what I was trying to get at is by last count earlier this year, there was perhaps a 300 super-spec rigs, to use a round number, and another 400 across the rest of the group that could be upgraded to that with -- under the conditions you discussed
componenttext: I guess what I was trying to get at is by last count earlier this year, there was perhaps a 300 super-spec rigs, to use a round number, and another 400 across the rest of the group that could be upgraded to that with -- under the conditions you discussed earlier, which are pretty simple. So if that's the case, what I'm saying, it seems like the supply of available rigs to do that kind of work seems like it's pretty considerable relative to where the horizontal rig count is today. And you know that there's a subset that's not necessarily looking for this pad-optimal work. So I just -- that's what I was trying to get is just the slack seems like there's still a good bit out there, outside of the optionality you guys have.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, and that's part of the problem is it's not quite -- the "super-spec" rig isn't as transparent as I'm sure everybody would like, and I think everybody's, to a degree, working from a different definition. We've seen a range published of 150 to
componenttext: Right. Well, and that's part of the problem is it's not quite -- the "super-spec" rig isn't as transparent as I'm sure everybody would like, and I think everybody's, to a degree, working from a different definition. We've seen a range published of 150 to 250 rigs that are "super-spec." There's a little over 700 1,500-horsepower rig, AC rigs, but we don't believe all those have the capability to be upgraded to super-spec capacity. They don't have the mast structure; they don't have the higher hook load capacity. I think there's a fewer number of rigs than people are anticipating that are capable of doing the kind of work that's being done. But again, that's our perspective. It's hard to nail it down because you don't have all the facts.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. That's a very fair point. Those would be important caveats. The last piece I guess to end this would be, are -- for these upgrades that you're doing, are you effectively willing to fund them on spec? Or is the idea that you need to get some le
componenttext: Understood. That's a very fair point. Those would be important caveats. The last piece I guess to end this would be, are -- for these upgrades that you're doing, are you effectively willing to fund them on spec? Or is the idea that you need to get some level of increase in rate to justify that capital commitment?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, up to this point, it's been the price of admission to work the rig in the areas where it's been needed. And again, not all rigs need it. I think -- what is it, David, 80% of our working fleet is super-spec, is that close?
componenttext: Well, up to this point, it's been the price of admission to work the rig in the areas where it's been needed. And again, not all rigs need it. I think -- what is it, David, 80% of our working fleet is super-spec, is that close?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we still have customers that don't need that, the higher spec. So -- but our intent is to get paid for that. I think, in general, we're probably getting paybacks in 1 to 2 years is kind of the way we're looking at it. But I think, in a lot of cases, th
componenttext: So we still have customers that don't need that, the higher spec. So -- but our intent is to get paid for that. I think, in general, we're probably getting paybacks in 1 to 2 years is kind of the way we're looking at it. But I think, in a lot of cases, that's going to be the price of admission to compete on these wells.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. At this time, I'll turn the call back over to our speakers for closing comments.
componenttext: Thank you. At this time, I'll turn the call back over to our speakers for closing comments.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Tony, thank you.I want to just quickly thank each of you again for joining us on the call today. And before I -- we sign off here, just a couple of quick, final thoughts. Just to reiterate, we believe our AC FlexRig fleet is positioned to tak
componenttext:
All right, Tony, thank you.
I want to just quickly thank each of you again for joining us on the call today. And before I -- we sign off here, just a couple of quick, final thoughts. Just to reiterate, we believe our AC FlexRig fleet is positioned to take market share in a strong or even a moderate U.S. land market recovery. We think we're uniquely leveraged to provide E&P companies the rig of choice to drill the more challenging horizontal wells. The design of our FlexRig fleet allows for a broad range of rig upgrades, providing a family of solutions for our customers.
So we thank you again for your time, and have a good day.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This does conclude today's conference. You may disconnect at any time, and have a great day.
componenttext: Thank you. This does conclude today's conference. You may disconnect at any time, and have a great day.
